Review Summary
Cross Current
Christine King
Ballantine, Oct 2004, $23.95, 320 pp.
ISBN: 0345448294

While waiting to tug a boat filled with Haitian refugees, Seychelle notices another vessel out in the gulf and takes her ship the Garda there. She finds a young dehydrated girl named Solange with a dead woman. She rescues the girl and tugs the boat containing the deceased to the dock. The Haitian refugee says that her father lives in the United States.   Seychelle intends to find him so that Solange will not be deported.

There has been a recent increase in the smuggling of Haitians into America. Seychelle believes that Solange and the dead woman were on a boat that capsized with fifty Haitians aboard. Solange is not safe as thugs try to kidnap her although neither Seychelle nor she can determine why. Those Haitians that survive have been sold into slavery making it even more difficult for Seychelle to gain their trust so that she can locate Solange's father. Kidnappers abduct Seychelle and Solange taking them to Bimini where they meet the smugglers' mastermind. The criminal tosses Seychelle overboard expecting her to die while he carries out his plans for Solange.

Harriet Klausner

Harriet Klausner, Resident Scholar

KEYNOTE SPEAKER

  Christine King
President and Chief Executive Officer
AMI Semiconductor

Christine King was named president and chief executive officer of AMI Semiconductor (NASDAQ: AMIS) in September 2001, becoming the first woman CEO of a semiconductor company.

King brought leadership and vision to AMIS, strengthening its strategy and corporate objectives to become a recognized industry leader with a strong market position.

As the company continued to flourish, King led AMIS through two successful acquisitions, including the mixed-signal business of Alcatel Microelectronics and the micro power products division of MicroSemi Corp. This business expansion strengthened the company’s growth potential through the addition of strategic technology resources with established market share.

Building upon the company’s financial results and successful acquisitions, King, within the first two years of her tenure, led AMIS through a $600 million initial public offering on the NASDAQ, notably the largest and most well received IPO of the semiconductor industry in 2003.

Prior to AMIS, King’s 23 years of experience at IBM included launching the company’s ASIC business in 1993 and growing it into the number one ASIC business in the world with $1.7 billion in revenue, as reported by Gartner Dataquest.

King began her career at IBM as a staff engineer holding a variety of engineering positions garnering recognition throughout the semiconductor industry for her technical expertise and knowledge. After a brief leave to lead a microprocessor systems and hardware-software development start-up, King returned to IBM to develop the company’s strength in ASICs, ultimately becoming vice president of Semiconductor Products for IBM Microelectronics.

King earned her bachelor’s degree in Electrical Engineering from Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck, N.J. She currently lives in Pocatello, Idaho, where AMIS is headquartered.

World class

World class?

Christine King

Vice-chancellor of Staffordshire University in the UK

Tuesday November 18, 2003


Christine King, vice-chancellor of Staffordshire University
I would say we are world class in that we have students from all over the world and, importantly, we have partnerships with universities, colleges and businesses all over the world. And we have 8,000 students studying for our degrees abroad. World class for us is about the right teaching, innovation and skills, rather than Nobel prizes.

There is the reputation of British higher education, and then the judgment that individuals make when they come here. The point about British universities is that we offer such a range of activities and skills. As a whole we're seen as world class, but within that it's about the right partners finding one another.

If world class means research dominated, then that is clearly not important to a university which is focused on student success and enterprise. It's probably important to our reputation, but it's important that that's not seen as the only element of what we can offer. The government speaking about this does tend to focus on research partnerships overseas and it isn't all about research.

We're not based on Nobel prizes, but student success and skills, as well as rebuilding and regenerating communities. That's the lifeblood of what we do and you need more of that than you need Nobel prize-winners.

Every university I know that is active overseas is extremely concerned about maintaining quality overseas.

We are accountable to QAA [the Quality Assurance Agency]. It's how we work. We won't keep our home customers if the quality isn't right. If you have a Nobel prize-winner as your alumni, that builds your reputation. But if you're a university like Staffordshire you've got to win your reputation. We just wouldn't do the business and we wouldn't expand if we weren't providing good experiences.

We have growing numbers [of students] from China, but many more doing joint teaching in countries where university systems are emerging - such as China and Malaysia. There is a danger of a British imperialism with education, but we work in partnerships with other institutions and not franchises. That's the future.
Polly Curtis

Ms. King has been president, chief executive officer and a director since September 2001. From September 2000 to September 2001, Mr. King was a vice president of Semiconductor Products for IBM Microelectronics. From September 1998 to September 2000, Ms. King was vice president of the Networking Technology Business Unit for IBM. Ms. King serves on the board of Analog Devices, Inc., a semiconductor company.

PROFESSIONAL ISSUE

CAREER OPPORTUNITIES
Search Our Site:
Christine King, AMI Semiconductor
 

"When our baby son was a year old my hippie husband left us for California," Christine King remembers. It was the 1960s, and no one was eager to hire a very young single mother without much education. "I went on welfare, talked my case worker into letting me go to college and was halfway to a teaching degree when I decided to take some engineering electives. It was totally by mistake that I ever got into this field."

Turned out she was very good at it. She got a two-year degree from the nearby community college in Orange County, NY in 1972 and started at IBM Microelectronics (Fishkill, NY) as a technician. She got her BS in 1976 from Fairleigh Dickinson University (Teaneck, NJ).

She spent twenty-three years at IBM, most recently as VP of semiconductor products for IBM Micro. She launched IBM's ASIC business in 1994 and its networking business in 1998. Other positions included sales and marketing at various IBM sites.

As time passed, King realized she "wanted to be a CEO and the one shaping the company." The right opportunity didn't arise until she was approached by AMIS in 2001.

AMIS, founded in 1966, designs, manufactures, markets and sells digital and mixed-signal ASICS and related conversion services. King is a recognized ASIC expert, so the appointment was a terrific fit.

"I came out and saw terrific talent here that I felt I could shape into a beautiful picture. How could I pass it up?"

D/C

FEBRUARY 2004

Interview: Professor Christine King Farris
by Joan Baum, Ph.D.

Perhaps it is because on that fateful day, April 3, 1968, just hours before his assassination in Memphis, Martin Luther King spoke so eloquently of God's allowing him to go up to the mountain where he saw the promised land, that this man among men has become enshrined in myth as a man still on the mountain: heroic, larger than life, mythical. He was a giant among men, and he had a dream that still haunts and inspires millions around the world, but he was first a boy, a typical fun-loving child, who before he knew he wanted to turn the world around joked with his friends, played piano, would horse around in the backyard with some white kids, before he learned why he no longer could. Having others understand the young Martin Luther King, identifying with his typical childhood, is extremely important to Christine King Farris, his older sister. Her dream is to have people, especially young black children, understand that Martin could indeed be a model for them because he was no different. To that end, she wrote a remarkable book about her brother, her second, My Brother Martin: A Sister Remembers Growing Up with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.(2003), with pictures by the award-winning children's book illustrator Chris Soentpiet, that is designed to bring Martin back down from the mountain and make him an accessible, influential role model.

She travels a lot across the country, reading from the book, and time and again realizes that so many youngsters think her brother "came from outer space"; that he was so extraordinary, that he must have been born extraordinary. Showing that Martin Luther King, Jr. had "a normal childhood" is important to her, she says, because only then can young readers-the book is slated for ages 9--12-really identify with him, appreciate the significance of having a close-knit and loving family, and realize that they, too, can be like Martin. "Everyone must try to achieve, "she says, regardless of background, and they will try if they see that their "hero" was a youngster like themselves, full of fun. She might as easily added, however, that her own life could be inspirational.

A Professor in the Department of Education at Spelman College, where she teaches and directs the Learning Resource Center-and is completing her 45th year!-Christine King Farris has a remarkable story to tell, which she promises to do in her next book, which will be geared for adults. An economics major at Spelman, where she got a B.A., she thought she would move into accounting, banking, and so she arrived in New York City at Columbia University, a young girl from the South, and entered a graduate program in economics. She was, she soon discovered, the only woman in the class and the only black, with a professor who expressed no interest in her. For all her "daring," the experience was "traumatic," and she withdrew. Just down the block, however, was Teachers College and a wonderful program in education and thus began study for her first Masters in education. A second would follow, with emphasis on reading and then more courses, until the Civil Rights movement claimed her attention. But she did teach in the Atlanta public schools for several years, at least until the public school system forced her out because she wanted to get married.

The apples do not fall far from the tree, however, if the tree gets nurturing. Her own children who had been close to Martin's still constitute a close family. Her daughter, who has a Ph.D. in psychology, teaches at Spelman, too, and treasures the photos of what she was too young to recall, of herself with her famous grandfather. But again, with compassion and firmness, Prof. Farris stresses how everyone can pursue the dream. Were Martin alive today, he would still be pushing for it, knowing that "we still do not have a level playing field." He gave us the "blueprint; we have to carry it out." And that "we" means everyone.# 

Christine King Farris is the older sister of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and an associate proffesor of education at Spelman College, Georgia.

CHRISTINE KING, AGE 36, FORDS

Published in the Home News Tribune 11/7/04

Christine Marie (Chapman) King, 36, of Fords died yesterday, Nov. 6, 2004, at Haven Hospice of JFK Medical Center, Edison.

Born Aug. 1, 1968, in Perth Amboy, she was raised in Colonia and resided in Fords for the past five years. Prior to that, she lived in Texas and Florida. She was a homemaker. She graduated from Klein High School in Spring, Texas.

She was a member of Our Lady of Peace R.C. Church in Fords. Christine, also fondly remembered as "Chrissie," was a lifelong friend to all animals, big and small. She was a horse trainer as well as a riding instructor. She was a member of the American Paint Horse Association. Christine loved the music of Tom Waits and reading the poetry of Charles Bukowski. She will be greatly missed by friends and family from near and far.

Predeceased by her late mother, Lenore Chapman in 2002, she is survived by her husband, Edward M. King of Fords; her father and stepmother, Stanley G. Jr. and Dana M. Chapman of Ponte Verde Beach, Fla.; a daughter, Stella B. King of Fords; a brother, Stanley G. Chapman III of Florida, and two stepbrothers, Daniel K. Chapman and Maxwell A. Chapman, both of Florida.

Funeral services will be held 8:30 a.m. Wednesday from Flynn and Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave., Fords, followed by a 9 a.m. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Peace R.C. Church. Cremation will be private. Visitation is Tuesday 2 p.m.-4 p.m. and 7 p.m.-9 p.m. Contributions may be made to the ASPCA in Eatontown c/o Flynn Charities Program. Condolence messages may be sent at www.flynnfuneral.com.

from the Home News Tribune

Published on November 7, 2004

Time for Kids; January 17, 2003; Winchester, Elizabeth

Winchester, Elizabeth

Time for Kids

January 17, 2003


Byline: Elizabeth Winchester
Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was once a kid, just like you. Now his big sister, Christine King Farris, 75, has written a book about growing up with him. It's called My Brother Martin. "I would like kids to know that Martin was a typical boy," Farris told TFK. "If I can get young people to understand that, then they too can make a difference in the world."
Farris and her two brothers grew up in Atlanta, Georgia. Their father was a minister, and their mother was a musician. The King kids loved jokes and pranks. They even fooled neighbors into thinking their grandmother's fur piece was a wild animal!
The King children were surrounded by love at home. But the world outside was often cruel and unjust. Their parents tried to shield them from unfair segregation laws that separated black and white people. That's why the family "rarely took streetcars or went to the movies," Farris explains.
Fighting for Equality

Dialog: With Christine King, CEO of AMI Semiconductor


It is never an easy path to reach the heights of chief executive-dom, and given that there are still hardly any female examples in the testosterone charged world of electronics, it is an even greater measurement of the achievements of Christine King. In little more than two years as CEO, she has transformed AMI Semiconductor (AMIS) from an ASIC 'also ran' into one of the most vibrant and inventive companies in this sector. All without a Y chromosome in sight. She talks with EPN's Mike Green.


Dialog: With Christine King, CEO of AMI Semiconductor

Some estimates suggest that Structured ASICs could represent revenues of as much as $7 Billion by 2007 (roughly a third of the overall TAM for ASICs). At first there were just a few companies pushing the concept, however some of the big players are now waking up to the potential of this technology. Also the main programmable logic firms are now looking at FPGA/ASIC hybrids that can serve this middle ground of 10 to 50 thousand units a year. With so many trying to jostle for a piece of this action, are you worried that AMIS (one of the first companies to champion these devices) might get squeezed out?
I clearly see it as a big opportunity, though I would question whether or not it will reach those heights so quickly. I think that the structured ASIC business will be split in to two areas. The platform solutions for medium complexity design will, as you mentioned, be very competitive. But our expertise is specifically in FPGA replacement. This requires the ability to understand both programmable logic and ASIC design, and we feel we have mastered that pretty well, so that's the area we are going to focus on. We are looking to take on the likes of Altera, and Xilinx, as opposed to Fujitsu, NEC, or LSI Logic, and we are very confident we have the talent to do it.

With all this potential competition in the Structured ASIC space, getting the right mix of unit cost, turnaround time, number of gates, and power consumption is vital. Each solution may have attributes that suit specific volume and performance characteristics, and none of them can claim to be the best across the whole spectrum of technical and economic requirements. How do you ensure that AMIS hits the richest vein?
I think the priorities must be cost leverage, first and foremost, then time to market is very important, and the other is requiring the lowest amount of participation from the customer, as they don't want to use up a lot of engineering resources in doing the conversrsion. There is a cost benefit in converting, and the quicker and more seamlessly it can be done, the greater the rewards will be. Obviously you have to match the FPGA in performance and power consumption, but this is normally not a problem, as they leave a lot of leeway in their design. So it's not important to have the highest number of gates or the smallest architectures it's keeping the cost to a minimum. Having your own fabs and utilising older technology for personalisation is a great value proposition here.

With the move to lower architectures, and larger wafers, the cost of establishing new fabs will obviously balloon. Doesn't this put you at a higher risk than larger ASIC firms, who's spend on new manufacturing equipment and EDA tools can be balanced against their higher revenues?
I think size and scale definitely helps, and pre-acquisition of Alcatel's mixed signal operations, we were probably a little bit sub-scale. But now I think we are adequate. In the analogue and mixed signal field there's still a lot of legs in 6" and 8" fabs. We have many customers that run low or medium volume analogue or mixed signal products that larger fabs would have a problem with. We are often seen as the "last fab standing', so when someone else goes out of the business, those customers who need to continue the life of these designs come to us. Deals that are now in place with STMicroelectronics and Intersil, to produce specific lines for them, will help cover the rising overheads of in-house manufacturing, and we'll continue to look for more opportunities of this kind.

The automotive sector represents an important revenue generator for your company. Which applications do you think will bring you most return on investment, and which companies are you working with on these projects?
The two areas where AMIS has the most strength are in sensor interface (whether its angular momentum sensing, or pressure sensing for brake or lighting systems), and high voltage (in terms of climate control, seat adjustment, etc). Many of our customers for these devices are to be found in Europe, they include Hella, Seimens VDO, Bosch, and so on. Pretty much everybody who is anybody in the automotive tier 1's uses AMIS silicon.

Car manufacturers will push for the market acceptance of the various forms of X-by-Wire between now and the end of the decade. However, it is likely that the public will be reluctant to embrace this controversial technology. How will these companies overcome the stigma that it is likely to produce?
In X-by-Wire we have to be very clear about reliability, compared to mechanical systems. Of course, mechanical systems have failures and problems as well. So I think we have to articulate the data and reassure people of its benefits. It's certainly a lot easier and less expensive to build in redundancy, and if we look at the aviation industry we already have Fly-by-Wire, in aircraft like the Airbus, where safety is at least as important. It just because it's a new concept that people are suspicious of it.

You opened an Automotive Centre near Detroit, in order to have greater synergy with the leading North American car makers. Has the project proved successful, and are there plans to establish a similar facility in Europe, given the region's importance in the automotive electronics market?
Well first of all, yes we do think it has been successful, particularly with the acceptance of some of the in-vehicle networking parts that we have. I think that Europe is a little bit smaller geographically, so it's easier to get around. Also it tends to be dominated by a small number of major players, so often we have engineers on site at these manufacturers.

With greater emphasis being put on tackling health problems at an early stage, through remote diagnosis and self monitoring, there will be a growing need for compact, long battery life medical devices like implantable heart monitors, glucose meters, defibrillators, and so on. AMIS has introduced a series of SOC solutions to tap into this market, what are your predictions for its growth?
From the second half of 2002 through to the first half of 2003 our sales in this market increased by 22%, and the analysts are predicting 21% growth in 2003 to 2004, so I think that this sector will continue to grow at a CAGR of around 20% for several years to come. And although its is a relatively small part of the semiconductor business there are barriers to entry, so it's very difficult for a newcomer to establish themselves. It needs a certain technical competence, and a demonstration of commitment to the long life and quality of these products. This is an area where we have been engaged for a long period of time, and now it's really starting to take off.

Your ASTRIC low data rate/cost effective communication chips lend themselves to automotive, medical, and industrial control applications. But as all of these sectors tend have very long design cycles, does this mean that it is still hard to judge whether the products these devices are incorporated into will successfully make the transition to higher volumes?
Well, with long design cycles like those in medical or industrial applications, you normally find that once the investment is made, the large majority of these designs go into production. So I feel there is now so much interest in incorporating wireless technology into these devices, that it leaves little doubt that they will be successful in reaching production. We already have a small number of designs in volume levels, mainly in the security area, and I think that the commitment of our customers is a good indication that this will increase.

Your acquisition of both Alcatel's and Microsemi's mixed signal outfits have given AMIS strong foot holds in the automotive and medical sector, as well as increasing the company's revenue by 50%. Do you feel that the company is now in a good position to move forward, or will there be further changes?
First of all, nobody could have wished for a better acquisition than the one we had with Alcatel, it was a deal made in heaven. One of the things that also made it successful was that we fully integrated the teams immediately, and took the best practices from each. I think the strength we now have can be seen from the financials as well as our customers' satisfaction, but we are always looking to grow, and will continue to search for potential acquisitions that will solidify our market share and broaden our technology capabilities.

Though clearly expanding the company's operations are still relatively small, and so building a good relationship with your distributors must be very important. Who are you working most closely with, and how do you ensure you get the best results for them?
You can never underestimate the power of relationships. Because of my tenure in charge of the ASIC division of IBM, I know the CEOs and presidents of many of the biggest companies very well, it allows you to call a lot of personal favours, and this gives us a presence beyond our real size. I try to be very visible, getting involved in many different events, do plenty of keynote speeches, etc. Networking means a lot, so we rely greatly on that. When it comes to distributors, it's actually only around 1% of our business. The number of customers in the markets we occupy is relatively small, and so we look to have direct contact with them.

Although women are now getting many of the top roles in business and political circles, when it comes to hi-tech you still have very few female peers. Is it simply that there are just not enough female engineers out there, and this slims the odds of making it to the top, or do you think that there is something more to it than this?
Certainly as both engineers and executives, women have good attributes, and are capable of attaining these roles. I think that there are two basic reasons why this isn't happening. One is the pipeline. Women are not lead into engineering, just because we still have these stereo-types. I think the female technical community must be committed to speaking to girls at a younger age, to tell them what a great career it can be. Secondly there is still a 'glass ceiling' effect. In large organisations, usually as women are moving through the lower ranks they get a lot of support from the top executives, but when they rise to the level of the more powerful men in the industry, they start to be seen as a threat, and there is a reluctance to help them to climb any further. I really think that there will be a new generation entering this business that will be a lot more open to women.

It's taken around 40 years for the semiconductor industry to get its first female CEO (namely you). Do you think it will be as long before we get the second?
No, I think at worst it's got to have a half-life.

FEBRUARY 2004

My Brother Martin
by Christine King Farris
Reviewed by Merri Rosenberg

My Brother Martin by Christine King Farris.
Illustrated by Chris Soentpiet.
Published by Simon & Schuster, 2003.

In time both for the observance of the late Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr's birthday, as well as for Black History Month, this delightful book makes a distinctive contribution to the many volumes devoted to Dr. King's life.

Written by his sister, the sole surviving sibling of the original three children, this picture book offers a cozy introduction to Dr. King that removes him from the pedestal as an iconic figure, and restores a refreshing human dimension that would engage young readers. I imagine that this book would work best as a read-aloud for second and third graders, whether at home or in a classroom setting.

Farris, herself an associate professor of education and director of the Learning Resource Center at Spelman College, describes a childhood remarkable both for the compelling presence of an extended family (devoted grandparents and aunt, who were strong influences on the King children) and for its relative innocence despite the undeniable racism and segregation of Jim Crow South.

There are charming anecdotes of childhood pranks, like scaring the neighbors with their grandmother's realistic fur piece, or loosening the legs of the piano bench so that the piano teacher came crashing down when he sat there. There are evocative descriptions of hearing family stories from their grandmother and aunt, and recollections of memorable dinners gathered around the expansive table.  And there are less pleasant episodes as well, like the time their white playmates told the young Martin and his brother that they couldn't play with them anymore because they were black, or when a shoe salesman wouldn't serve Martin and his father unless they went to the back of the store (no surprise that the elder Dr. King took his business elsewhere).

Farris includes a story that prefigures just how significant Dr. King's leadership would ultimately become. After the white children had shunned young Martin, and he asked his mother why "white people treat colored people so mean", her answer, "Because they just don't understand that everyone is the same, but someday, it will be better," triggered his prophetic response. Martin told his mother, "one day, I'm going to turn this world upside down."

And so he did. And perhaps this glimpse of the young Dr. King as a child-not a saint or extraordinary youngster-will inspire similar bold dreams.#

See our interview with the author. ****Link This Rick*****

Fighting talk?

 

Should we adopt a military approach when we talk about managing Higher Education? We use the language of warfare - strategy, tactics, mission, bullets - but we retain our democratic structures. External forces demand that universities change for survival. How do we respond to these management challenges?

Professor Christine King shared her vision at the Association of University Administrators conference, hosted this year by the University of Exeter. The Vice-Chancellor of Staffordshire University urged over 1,000 delegates to embrace change and be instrumental in the changes that are taking place in the higher education sector.

In meeting the challenges that HE faces, she sees excellent management as a vital tool. People will deliver the change, but they need to be empowered to do so and the goals they are working towards need to be shared. A military approach is not necessarily what is required, but leadership is.

However, Christine King does not describe a dictatorship. Instead a community where everyone is able to contribute and engage in the activities which make the vision a reality; a community built on openness, listening and sharing. Disappointments are not hidden. A real culture of celebrating success and publicising achievement is encouraged. Professor King believes in starting every meeting with an opportunity for colleagues to tell each other their good news.

Individuals are key to the community, and leadership can help harness their potential. At Staffordshire change has been embraced. From a lack of customer focus, they now put students at the heart of everything they do. With this vision in mind it is clear that everyone in the university has an important role to play, not only the teachers. For example, taking student retention as a key indicator of success, the all-round student experience becomes critical. All areas of student support go under the spotlight and new services developed, including the creation of 24-hour kiosk services.

A team approach between all university colleagues is recommended as central to success. Partnerships across academic, professional and support staff must be encouraged to enable universities to meet the challenge of the future. Decision-making and management of activities changes as project teams work together to deliver the vision. In Staffordshire this has had the effect of abolishing minute taking in favour of action points and even some committees disbanding themselves.

Professor King did not pursue the military approach during her talk, but she did make good headway in rallying the troops. Her confidence in the value of the Higher Education sector was obvious, as was her sense of privilege working in an area so critical to the economic and cultural future of the nation. Her parting message was that change is good, and should be welcomed and managed. She calls on her audience to take pride in their achievements and to enjoy the thrill and the challenge of changing peoples lives.

Development Services    

H. Christine King
Director of Research Development Services
Phone: (765) 494-6706; Fax: (765) 494-8323
E-mail:hcking@purdue.edu

Christine King acts as a starting point for faculty seeking funding from external sponsors, particularly federal agencies. She disseminates funding opportunities and trains faculty in the use of the Community of Science funding databases. Cris works individually with faculty seeking assistance in the development and submission of research and education proposals, and helps connect them with others who can provide assistance or collaboration. She facilitates the development of research collaborations, and particularly promotes the development of individual and university-wide proposals with an emphasis on education.

Cris has bachelor's and master's degrees in education. She came to Purdue in 1998 with five years' experience in research development and research administration at the University of Georgia and Southern Illinois University, and with four years' experience in faculty development at DePauw University.

Christine is a co-moderator of the Teaching in Taiwan forum

Christine is from the suburbs of Los Angeles. In college at UCLA, her Chinese American friends introduced her to such novel concepts as red bean desserts, "potstickers" and "hotpot." Then, dating a Taiwanese man, she began to learn Mandarin as well as more about Taiwan in general.

Always having wanted to experience living in another country, Christine decided to move to Taiwan for a year and teach English. She enjoyed it so much that she decided to stay another year. She also earned a TESL certificate. She's been in Taipei more than five years now and has worked at a variety of different language schools, though she prefers teaching adult classes. She is recently married to a wonderful Taiwanese man (not the one mentioned above), also an English teacher.

While Christine enjoys teaching, she is often frustrated by the lack of professionalism in language schools as well as the lack of a larger professional English teaching community where teachers could share their experiences and ideas. She would love to see more professional education opportunities on the island.

Christine can be reached at cking@oriented.org

About the Authors

EQUINE LAMENESS

Christine M. King, BVSc, MACVSc, MVetClinStud is an Australian veterinarian who spent several years in equine practice in Australia before moving to the United States. She completed a Masters degree in equine exercise physiology at the University of Sydney. She is currently working as a veterinary writer.






E-mail the authors c/o Equine Research, Inc.

Back to the book

Richard A. Mansmann, VMD, PhD earned his PhD in comparative pathology from the University of California at Davis. He has written and edited several books and journal articles, and served on the editorial board of the Journal of Equine Veterinary Science. He is involved with equine rescue and humane organizations and believes strongly in owner education. His veterinary practice focuses on foot conditions, respiratory conditions, chronic ailments in sporthorses, and older horse care.

MY BROTHER MARTIN

BUY THIS BOOK

Author: Christine King Farris
Illustrator: Chris Soentpiet

Grade: K-up/Ages 5 and up

40 color illustrated pages
11"X 10" picture book
$17.95 ISBN # 0-689-84387-9
CAN:$25.99

Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
1230 Avenue of Americas
New York, NY 10020
(800) 223-2348
www.simonsays.com

  • Child Magazine Best Book of 2003
  • IRA Teachers' Choice for 2004
  • NAACP Image Award: Outstanding Literary Work 2004


ABOUT THIS BOOK:
Long before he became a world-famous dreamer, Martin Luther King Jr. was a little boy who played jokes and practiced the piano and made friends without considering race. But growing up in the segregated South on the 1930's forced a very young Martin to learn a bitter lesson - little white children and little black children were not to play with one another. Martin decided then and there that something had to be done. And as a seven-year old, he embarked on a journey that would change the course of American history.

Renowed educator Christine King Farris, older sister of the late Dr. King, tells this inspirational story of how one boyhood experience inspired a movement. It's a tale that will touch the hearts of all people, and remind us all that if you believe hard enough, dreams can become reality.

MY THOUGHTS OF "MY BROTHER MARTIN":

"About two years ago, I was preparing to give a speech at a teacher conference. Distracted in my preparations, I wasn't fully aware of the person introducing me. As it turned out, that person was Mrs. Christine King Farris, sister of the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. She sat through my presentation and afterward asked if I would be interested in working with her on a project-a book about her childhood with her brother. Of course, I was incredibly flattered. As a youngster, I had idolized this remarkable human being. She went on to say that I and the things I said during my presentation reminded her of her brother. I felt truly honored.

Christine and I kept in contact and soon Mrs. Farris's editor at Simon and Schuster contacted me. Within a matter of weeks the book was underway. My first course of action, a trip to the King Center in Atlanta where Mrs. Farris, our editor, and I walked through the places of Dr. King's childhood-his home, his church, the neighborhood firehouse where he and his friends spent much of their time-all while discussing what we thought this book should be. I snapped photographs and listened while Mrs. Farris regaled us with recollections of a childhood spent with a little boy who would grow up to change the world. I was moved beyond words and left Atlanta with the feeling of being a part of something historic.

I returned to Atlanta for a second time with my camera, lighting equipment, backdrop, and clothes for the models to wear. Because I paint realistically I need to use live models to ensure the main characters look the same from one angle to another. Christine greeted me at Ebenezer Baptist Church with southern graciousness and charm. She personally chose each model to represent the character in her story.

The boys who portrayed Martin Jr. and AD are Christine's grandnephew. Christine's daughter portrayed "Mother Dear". The current pastor at Ebenezer Baptist portrayed "Daddy" King. Even Christine's young granddaughter was an eager model. The rest of the cast were personal and close friends of the King family. The models shared with me interesting stories of their time with Dr. King, which helped me visualize the illustration process. All the models agreed their participation was a special tribute to Dr. King's legacy.

Christine's presence added another element of authenticity to my photo shoot. For example, did you know Aunt Ida did not go to church-so I made sure I did not to paint her in a church scene.

As part of my painting process, I also sketched the original King's childhood home on 510 Auburn Avenue in Atlanta, which is now preserved by The King Center.

The spirit and generosity from Mrs. Farris, the staff at both the Ebenezer Baptist Church and the National Historic Site, and the King family helped to make my work on MY BROTHER MARTIN as genuine and authentic as I think possible. It is my sincere hope that the part I played in the creation of this book helps Dr. King's vision of justice and harmony live on and on. -Chris Soentpiet

*** Learn how you can preserve Dr. King's legacy by visiting The King Center.

BOOK REVIEW:

This stunningly beautiful picture book for children of all ages features sunny watercolors that capture the King family at home with warmth and love. A few black and white watercolor paintings that focus on King's adult life bring up the end, along with Mildred D. Johnson's poem "You Can Be Like Martin" and an author's afterword. Few books are a "must read." This is one.
-Deborah Abbott (Chicago Sun-Times. Jan 2003)

TEACHERS ACTIVITY GUIDE:
Theme: MY BROTHER MARTIN can be used to introduce your students to the life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., African-Americans and race relations. This year marks the 40th anniversary of the "I Have A Dream" speech. Use this book to talk about the civil rights movement and why the speech is a part of American history.

Pre-reading: Show the students the cover of the book, and then read the title, author and illustrator's name. Ask them what they think the book will be about. Explain that the sister will tell a story of her childhood growing up with her brother who later became world famous.

Reading: As you read and show the illustrations have the students look closely at the drawings. What details can they find in the pictures? Have them look closely at the expressions on the faces for the characters -- how do they change during the story. Ask the students how they think the characters are feeling? Can they tell by the illustrations? The childhood home is based in Atlanta, Georgia. Have a map nearby to see how far it is from you.

Social Studies/Literature: Read more about Dr. King, the civil-rights movement and African-American history by reading books like MOMMA, WHERE ARE YOU FROM by Marie Bradby, MORE THAN ANYTHING ELSE by Marie Bradby, MARTIN'S BIG WORDS by Doreen Rappaport, FREE AT LAST by Sara Bullard, THEY HAD A DREAM by Jules Archer, LET IT SHINE by Andrea Davis Pinkney.

If you enjoyed reading MY BROTHER MARTIN write a review and post it on-line at Amazon.com or Barnesandnoble.com so others can enjoy your reading experience.

Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr

Contact Information
501 Auburn Ave
Location:
Phone:404/331-6922

Hours:Daily 9am-5pm
Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day
Transportation:From I-75/85 south, exit at Freedom Parkway/Carter Center (248C). Turn right at first stoplight onto Boulevard. Follow signs to Martin Luther King, Jr., National Historic Site. MARTA: King Memorial Station is about 8 blocks away, or take bus no. 3 east from the Five Points Station
Price:Free admission


Martin Luther King, Jr. was born in this two-story Queen Anne-style house on January 15, 1929, the oldest son of a Baptist minister and an elementary school music teacher. His childhood was a normal one. He preferred playing baseball to piano lessons, liked to play board games, and got a kick out of tearing the heads off his older sister's dolls (nonviolence came later). To quote his sister, Christine King Farris, "My brother was no saint ordained at birth, instead he was an average and ordinary man, called by . . . God . . . to perform extraordinary deeds."

King lived here through the age of 12, then moved with his family to a house a few blocks away. A visit provides many insights into the formative influences on one of the greatest leaders of our time. The Rev. A. D. Williams, King's maternal grandfather and pastor of Ebenezer Baptist Church, bought the house in 1909. Reverend Williams was active not only in the church, but in the community and in early manifestations of the civil rights movement. He was a charter member of Atlanta's NAACP and led a series of black registration and voting drives as far back as 1917. He was instrumental in getting black officers on the Atlanta police force. Martin Luther King, Sr. moved in on Thanksgiving Day, 1926, when he married Williams's daughter Alberta. When Reverend Williams died in 1931, King became head of the household and took over Williams's pulpit at Ebenezer Church.

The King family retained ownership of the house at 501 Auburn even after they moved away. King's younger brother, Alfred Daniel, lived here with his family from 1954 to 1963. In 1971, King's mother deeded the home to the Martin Luther King, Jr. Center. It has since been restored to its appearance during the years of King's boyhood. The furnishings are all originals or similar period reproductions, and some personal items belonging to the family are on display. Christine was actively involved in the restoration, providing a wealth of detail about the former appearance of the house, as well as anecdotal material about life in the King family.

Tours of the house, conducted by National Park rangers, begin in the downstairs parlor, where you'll see family photographs showing Martin Luther as a child. The parlor was used for choir practice, for the dreaded piano lessons, and as a rec room where the family gathered around the radio to listen to shows like "The Shadow." In the dining room, world events were regularly discussed over meals, and every Sunday, before dinner, each child was required to recite a newly learned Bible verse from memory. You'll also see the coal cellar (stoking coal was one of King's childhood chores); the children's play area; the upstairs bedroom of King's parents in which Christine, King, and Alfred Daniel were born; Reverend Williams's den, where the family gathered for nightly Bible study; the bedroom King shared with his brother ("always in disarray," says Christine); and Christine's bedroom.

Note: In summer, especially, tickets often run out early; for your best chance to tour the home, arrive at 9am.

"Copyright 2004 Wiley Publishing, Inc."




265 Peachtree Street NE Atlanta, Georgia 30303USA

Christine King in the Hamilton District Court yesterday. Picture / Greg Bowker

Tablets to 'calm' moody husband, court told

02.11.2004
 By NICOLA BOYES

Wayne Roycroft was a moody, irritable man who liked to drink, so his wife Christine gave him sleeping tablets.

She told friends and family the tablets were to "calm" him.

Nearly 16 years later, now known as Christine King, she has been charged with murdering him.

At a depositions hearing in the Hamilton District Court yesterday King, 50, listened quietly as witnesses give their evidence.

But as some described the good relationship they believed the couple shared, King would briefly roll her eyes.

The same witnesses described her husband as a man who liked to drink, liked a tidy house, did not work and did not like King going out with friends or to work herself, leaving their children at home.

It was November 1988 when Mr Roycroft, then 35, disappeared from the Waihou home he shared with King, who he had married in 1984. He was reported missing in June 1989.

This May, a tip-off led police back to Waihou, near Te Aroha.

King was arrested and charged with murdering her husband around November 19, 1988.

Mr Roycroft's sister-in-law Maureen Roycroft remembered a Monday when she and her husband Brett visited the couple's home.

As they knocked on the door King and her daughter pulled up in the family's muddy blue station wagon, she told the court.

"Christine told us that Wayne had left last night, had taken some stuff and gone. Some joker had picked him up."

Mr Roycroft's belongings littered the home's kitchen and the couple's bedroom had been changed around.

King, who had been wearing muddy gumboots, appeared nervous, she said.

On the way out Mrs Roycroft noticed a muddy shovel in the car.

The couple "had the odd fight, which every couple does", she said.

The arguments were mainly about the house being messy. Her brother, who was not working, liked a tidy house and King, who was working, didn't just leave it untidy, she left it "really messy", Mrs Roycroft said.

Mr Roycroft's mother Aileen told the court that while visiting the couple's home, she saw King put something in Mr Roycroft's beer.

"She said I'm giving him this to make him not be violent or not really be violent and ah, he just went to sleep," she told the court.

"She said 'oh it's just something to calm him down'."

When her son went missing she said King told her he had gone off with someone else.

Under cross-examination by Judith Ablett Kerr, QC, Mrs Roycroft said she was not happy about the couple's relationship because, although they had two children together, she worried about King's two daughters from a previous relationship.

She said her son liked to drink, was a moody man who could be irritable and "liked to be the boss".

She never told her son about King putting something in his drink.

"I just thought that'll start another argument.

"I didn't want him to take it out on anyone."

June Godfrey, who ran a store in Te Aroha, said King and Mr Roycroft would often pop in to see her and their relationship seemed good.

King told her one day she had been putting sleeping tablets in Mr Roycroft's dinner.

King was annoyed because Mr Roycroft would take the mileage on her car and follow her to work.

"She said she had put sleeping tablets in his dinner so he wouldn't follow her to work."

The case continues today.

The case

* November 1988: Wayne Roycroft, 35, goes missing from the Waihou home he shared with Christine King

* Seven months later: Roycroft reported missing

* May 2004: King charged with murdering her husband around November 19, 1988.

My Brother Martin: A Sister Remembers Growing Up with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
by Christine Ki Farris

Age Level: 09-12
Condition: Standard

ISBN: 0689843879 Subtitle: A Sister Remembers Growing Up with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ill.: Soentpiet, Chris K. Author: Soentpiet, Chris K. Publisher: Simon & Schuster Children's Publishing Subject: King family Subject: African Americans Subject: Atlanta Subject: Social conditions Subject: Georgia Subject: General Subject: Biography & Autobiography - Social Activists Subject: Biography & Autobiography - Religious Subject: Biography & Autobiography - People of Color Subject: Children's 9-12 - Biography / Autobiography Subject: Historical Edition Number: 1st ed. Series Volume: 71-0077 Publication Date: January 2003 Binding: Hardcover Language: English Illustrations: Yes Pages: 40 Dimensions: 10.36x12.26x.40 in. 1.31 lbs.


Publisher Comments:
Long before he became a world-famous dreamer, Martin Luther King Jr. was a little boy who played practical jokes and made friends without any consideration to race. But growing up in the segregated South of the 1920s taught a very young Martin a bitter lesson. In that world, little white children and little black children were not supposed to play with one another. And when one heartbreaking incident made that fact clear, the young Martin realized his calling in life and set out on a path that would ultimately change the course of American history.

For the first time, Christine King Farris, older sister of the slain civil rights leader, tells firsthand the story behind the story. Join her and celebrated illustrator Chris Soentpiet in the inspirational account of how one boyhood experience inspired a movement. It's a tale that will touch deeply the hearts of people of all ages and remind us all that if you believe hard enough, childhood dreams can become reality.

Synopsis:
The older sister of Dr. King relates how growing up in the segregated South of the 1920s taught her younger brother a bitter lesson. When an incident makes clear the fact that white children and black children are not to play together, young Martin realizes his calling in life, and sets out on a path that changes the course of American history. Full color.

back to top

Christine King Farris is the older sister of the late civil rights leader, the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. She is an associate professor of young adult education at Spelman College in Atlanta, Georgia, where she teaches courses in multiculturalism and elementary reading. This is her first book. She and her husband reside in Atlanta, Georgia.

Major King Events Chronology

1929-1953

next

|

print version

|


1929

15 January

Michael King, later known as Martin Luther King, Jr., is born at 501 Auburn Ave. in Atlanta, Georgia.


1941

Summer

The King family -- Martin Luther King, Sr. (Daddy King), Alberta Williams King, Willie Christine King, Martin Luther King, Jr., and Alfred Daniel Williams King (known as A. D. King) -- moves from 501 Auburn Avenue to 193 Boulevard in Atlanta.


1944

20 September

King begins his freshman year at Morehouse College in Atlanta.


1946

6 August

The Atlanta Constitution publishes King’s letter to the editor stating that black people "are entitled to the basic rights and opportunities of American citizens."


1947

January/February

King’s article, "The Purpose of Education" is published in the Morehouse student paper, the Maroon Tiger.


1948

25 February

King is ordained and appointed assistant pastor at Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta.

8 June

King receives his bachelor of arts degree in sociology from Morehouse College.

14 September

King begins his studies at Crozer Theological Seminary in Chester, Pennsylvania.


1951

6-8 May

King graduates from Crozer with a bachelor of divinity degree, delivering the valedictory address at commencement.

13 September

King begins his graduate studies in systematic theology at Boston University.


1953

18 June

King and Coretta Scott are married at the Scott home near Marion, Alabama.

User Reviews
There's no better Martin Luther King Jr. Book!
This is a straight forward, compassionate, informational story of Martin Luther King Jr.'s life. His sister tells their story simply and provides perspective where Martin Luther King Jr. got many of his ideas and courage - from his dad! It is a quiet appreciation for the life the family led. I really appreciated the story and it brings a new more realistic meaning to King's life.
A touching memior of the childhood that shaped the man
I LOVE this book. It is a well-written, personal account of a family. It spans from fun carefree days to the realization of prejudice. It is not about the man, it is about the boy. It was not graphic in it's description of violence and hatred, which made it completely appropriate for my six year old (who also really enjoyed the book). And the poem at the end was the perfect ending. GET THIS BOOK!
Unique Perspective
I loved this book because whenever i read a biogaphy I always want to hear from someone who really knew the person and in this book by Martin Luther King's sister, Christine King Farris, I get that perspective. Farris writes beautifully and poetically about their childhood and sheds light on the experiences and influences that shaped MLK to be the great inspirational leader that he was. I highly recommend this wonderful biography!

AMI Semiconductor Names Former IBM VP Christine King CEO

Pocatello, ID - Aug 31, 2001

AMI Semiconductor (AMIS), a world leader in conversion and mixed-signal application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs), today announced it has appointed Christine King as president and CEO. Ms. King, formerly vice president of IBM Microelectronics' Semiconductor Products, will take the helm at privately held AMIS on Sept. 10, bringing more than 25 years of direct industry experience to the position.

Ms. King most recently managed IBM's multi-billion-dollar semiconductor products business, which was the fastest growing business at IBM in the first quarter of this year. In addition, she launched IBM's OEM ASIC business in 1993, growing it to the number one ASIC business in the world by 1999.

"Acquiring a CEO with Chris' excellent qualifications is a real coup for AMIS," said Dipanjan Deb, AMIS board member and partner of Francisco Partners, a major AMIS investor. "Her outstanding relationships with ASIC customers throughout the industry - including some existing AMIS customers - will be a tremendous asset for AMIS immediately and in the future."

"I am very excited to have the opportunity to lead AMIS into what I am sure will be a very bright future," said King. "AMI Semiconductor's ability to provide the industry with effective highly integrated semiconductor solutions is truly impressive. Their undisputed technology and market leadership in conversion ASICs and significant technology edge in mixed-signal ASICs give me great ammunition for further strategic growth."

Building off of her experience in ASICs, Ms. King also launched IBM's networking technology semiconductor business and previously served as vice president of field engineering programs and global marketing. Prior to those positions, Ms. King held various engineering positions at IBM.

AMI Semiconductor Names Former IBM VP Christine King CEO

    

Pocatello, ID - August 31, 2001 - AMI Semiconductor (AMIS), a world leader in conversion and mixed-signal application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs), today announced it has appointed Christine King as president and CEO. Ms. King, formerly vice president of IBM Microelectronics' Semiconductor Products, will take the helm at privately held AMIS on Sept. 10, bringing more than 25 years of direct industry experience to the position.

Ms. King most recently managed IBM's multi-billion-dollar semiconductor products business, which was the fastest growing business at IBM in the first quarter of this year. In addition, she launched IBM's OEM ASIC business in 1993, growing it to the number one ASIC business in the world by 1999.

"Acquiring a CEO with Chris' excellent qualifications is a real coup for AMIS," said Dipanjan Deb, AMIS board member and partner of Francisco Partners, a major AMIS investor. "Her outstanding relationships with ASIC customers throughout the industry - including some existing AMIS customers - will be a tremendous asset for AMIS immediately and in the future."

"I am very excited to have the opportunity to lead AMIS into what I am sure will be a very bright future," said King. "AMI Semiconductor's ability to provide the industry with effective highly integrated semiconductor solutions is truly impressive. Their undisputed technology and market leadership in conversion ASICs and significant technology edge in mixed-signal ASICs give me great ammunition for further strategic growth."

Building off of her experience in ASICs, Ms. King also launched IBM's networking technology semiconductor business and previously served as vice president of field engineering programs and global marketing. Prior to those positions, Ms. King held various engineering positions at IBM.  

About AMI Semiconductor

AMI Semiconductor (AMIS) is a world leader in the design and manufacture of silicon solutions for the real world. As a widely recognized innovator in state-of-the-art mixed-signal technologies and mid-range digital ASICs including ASIC conversion services, AMIS is committed to providing customers with the optimal value, quickest time-to-market ASIC solutions. Offering unparalleled manufacturing flexibility and dedication to customer service, AMI Semiconductor operates globally with headquarters in Pocatello, Idaho, European corporate offices in Oudenaarde, Belgium, and a network of sales and design centers located in the key markets of the United States, Europe and the Asia Pacific region.

The king: nobody knows - Brief Article
Ebony,  Jan, 2004  

 
Save a personal copy of this article and quickly find it again with Furl.net. Get started now. (It's free.)

The private King (left) demonstrates his pool skills to Chicago youth during his Chicago open-housing campaign in the late 1960s. During a rare three-week Jamaica vacation (top), King cools off in a swimming pool and (below) works on his last book, Where Do We Go Front Here.

We see him large--in the spotlight, on the platform, moving and motivating millions. Few, outside family and close friends, saw and knew the family man, who loved a good joke and a good swim, and who considered himself something of a pool shark. Here, from the extensive EBONY files, is the private man who should also be celebrated and remembered.

Young Martin (left, front, r.) poses with his mother and father, the Rev. and Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., grandmother, Mrs. Jennie C. Williams (r.), brother A.D. and sister Christine. King and his sister (below) graduated from college on the same day in 1948. Christine King Farris received a B.A. in economics from Spelman College and King received a B.A. in sociology from Morehouse College, where he is shown (bottom) in chapel.

First child Yolanda Denise (left and below, right) is shown in portrait with parents, Dr. and Mrs. King, and is pushed in stroller near their Montgomery home. After King's release from Reidsville State Prison in October 1960 (below, left), he is greeted warmly by his wife and children.

Popular with children, Dr. King interacts with students and gets a hug from a young admirer in 1965.

Dressed to the hilt,

King shares spotlight with wife, Coretta, in 1964 after Nobel Peace Prize presentation in Oslo, Norway. In a moment of stillness and quiet, he relaxes on the beach with his wife, who is leading the national celebration of his birth.

My Brother Martin: a Sister Remembers Growing Up With the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr - Book Review
Black Issues Book Review,  Jan-Feb, 2003  by Lynda Jones

 
Save a personal copy of this article and quickly find it again with Furl.net. Get started now. (It's free.)

by Christine King Farris, illustrated by Chris Soentpiet Simon & Schuster, January 2003 $16.95, ISBN 0-689-84387-9

Every January on Martin Luther King Jr Day, broadcasts of the civil rights leader's "I Have a Dream," speech resound across the nation. Dr. King's accomplishments as a man are well known, but his experiences as a young boy are what inspired him to speak out against the unfair treatment of African Americans. In the picture book biography My Brother Martin, Dr. King's older sister Christine King Farris shares how her little brother grew up to become a beloved champion of civil rights.

The wonderfully moving story begins in Atlanta, where Christine, Martin and their youngest brother Alfred were born. Life is as normal as it can be in the segregated South. Young Martin and his siblings play checkers and Monopoly, take piano lessons and pull pranks on adults. They also hang out with the children of their white neighbors. ("The thought of not playing with those kids because they were different ... never entered our minds.") When the white kids unexpectedly announce to Martin and his brother that they can no longer play with Negroes, Martin is heartbroken. Inspired by the words of his outspoken pastor and father and ever-hopeful mother, the child proclaims, "Mother Dear, one day I'm going to turn this world upside down." The text fast forwards to the latter years of Dr. King's life, as he leads civil rights marches and protests, and eventually shares his inspirational dream of racial equality with the nation.

Chris Soentpiet's realistic and greatly detailed illustrations of the King family at home, in church and at play pull the reader into the story. Mrs. Farris' family and friends were used as the models for the personalities in the book. For young readers, My Brother Martin is an exceptional story about an ordinary boy who became an extraordinary man.

Editorial Reviews
 From Publishers Weekly
Farris's stirring memoir of her younger brother "M.L." focuses on a pivotal moment in their childhood in Atlanta. The conversational narrative easily and convincingly draws readers into the daily life of Christine and her two brothers, M.L. and A.D., as they listen to their grandmother's stories, stage pranks and romp in the backyard with two white brothers from across the street. The adults in the King family-Daddy, a minister; Mother Dear, a musician; maternal grandparents (the grandfather is also a minister) and a great-aunt-try to shield the children from the overt racism of the times; the family rarely took streetcars, for example, because of "those laws [segregation], and the indignity that went with them." When the white boys announce one day that they cannot play with M.L. and A.D. because they are "Negroes," the young Kings are hurt and baffled. Mother Dear explains, "[Whites] just don't understand that everyone is the same, but someday, it will be better." M.L. replies, "Mother Dear, one day I'm going to turn this world upside down." Soentpiet (Dear Santa, Please Come to the 19th Floor) illustrates this exchange with a powerful watercolor portrait of mother and son that encapsulates many emotions, including hope, pain and love. Unfortunately, in other paintings, the characters often seem frozen in exaggerated poses, or minor figures are rendered with less skill than demonstrated elsewhere. These inconsistencies detract from an otherwise gripping volume that makes the audience aware that heroes were once children, too. All ages.
Copyright 2002 Reed Business Information, Inc.

Using plain language, she describes conditions in the South during her childhood that separated blacks and whites- "Because they just don't understand that everyone is the same, but... read more

Book Description


Long before he became a world-famous dreamer, Martin Luther King Jr. was a little boy who played jokes and practiced the piano and made friends without considering race. But growing up in the segregated South of the 1920s forced a very young Martin to learn a bitter lesson -- little white children and little black children were not to play with one another. Martin decided then and there that something had to be done. And as a seven-year-old, he embarked on a journey that would change the course of American history.

Renowned educator Christine King Farris, older sister of the late Dr. King, joins with celebrated illustrator Chris Soentpiet to tell this inspirational story of how one boyhood experience inspired a movement. It's a tale that will touch the hearts of all people, and remind us all that if you believe hard enough, dreams can become reality.

There's no better Martin Luther King Jr. Book!, November 29, 2003
Reviewer:   A reader (Webster, NY United States)
This is a straight forward, compassionate, informational story of Martin Luther King Jr.'s life. His sister tells their story simply and provides perspective where Martin Luther King Jr. got many of his ideas and courage - from his dad! It is a quiet appreciation for the life the family led. I really appreciated the story and it brings a new more realistic meaning to King's life.

Was this review helpful to you?   (Report this)

 

4 of 4 people found the following review helpful:

A touching memior of the childhood that shaped the man, May 26, 2003
Reviewer:   A reader
I LOVE this book. It is a well-written, personal account of a family. It spans from fun carefree days to the realization of prejudice. It is not about the man, it is about the boy. It was not graphic in it's description of violence and hatred, which made it completely appropriate for my six year old (who also really enjoyed the book). And the poem at the end was the perfect ending. GET THIS BOOK!

Unique Perspective, February 18, 2003
Reviewer:   jeannie chang (Cal Poly Pomona) - See all my reviews
I loved this book because whenever i read a biogaphy I always want to hear from someone who really knew the person and in this book by Martin Luther King's sister, Christine King Farris, I get that perspective. Farris writes beautifully and poetically about their childhood and sheds light on the experiences and influences that shaped MLK to be the great inspirational leader that he was. I highly recommend this wonderful biography!

Editorial Reviews

From Publishers Weekly
Farris's stirring memoir of her younger brother "M.L." focuses on a pivotal moment in their childhood in Atlanta. The conversational narrative easily and convincingly draws readers into the daily life of Christine and her two brothers, M.L. and A.D., as they listen to their grandmother's stories, stage pranks and romp in the backyard with two white brothers from across the street. The adults in the King family-Daddy, a minister; Mother Dear, a musician; maternal grandparents (the grandfather is also a minister) and a great-aunt-try to shield the children from the overt racism of the times; the family rarely took streetcars, for example, because of "those laws [segregation], and the indignity that went with them." When the white boys announce one day that they cannot play with M.L. and A.D. because they are "Negroes," the young Kings are hurt and baffled. Mother Dear explains, "[Whites] just don't understand that everyone is the same, but someday, it will be better." M.L. replies, "Mother Dear, one day I'm going to turn this world upside down." Soentpiet (Dear Santa, Please Come to the 19th Floor) illustrates this exchange with a powerful watercolor portrait of mother and son that encapsulates many emotions, including hope, pain and love. Unfortunately, in other paintings, the characters often seem frozen in exaggerated poses, or minor figures are rendered with less skill than demonstrated elsewhere. These inconsistencies detract from an otherwise gripping volume that makes the audience aware that heroes were once children, too. All ages.
Copyright 2002 Reed Business Information, Inc.

From School Library Journal
Grade 2-4-In the straightforward style of a master storyteller, Farris recalls the birth of her two younger brothers and relates anecdotes that demonstrate both the mischievous exploits of the siblings and the love and understanding that permeated the close-knit multigenerational family in which they grew up. Using plain language, she describes conditions in the South during her childhood that separated blacks and whites- "Because they just don't understand that everyone is the same, but someday, it will be better." From their father's church sermons and his actions when confronting the hatred and bigotry, the children learned the importance of standing up for justice and equality. The warmth of the text is exquisitely echoed in Soentpiet's realistic, light-filled watercolor portraits set in the King home, in their Atlanta neighborhood, and at Ebenezer Baptist Church. The simple directness of this short biography will help young children understand the concept of segregation and the importance of Dr. King's message. An appended poem by Mildred D. Johnson reflects Farris's own message: "-it is important for young people to realize the potential that lies within each of them-." This outstanding book belongs in every collection.
Susan Scheps, Shaker Heights Public Library, OH
Copyright 2003 Reed Business Information, Inc.

From Booklist
K-Gr. 3. In this picture-book biography, Martin Lunter King's older sister adds a personal stamp to King's childhood experiences that other books have lacked. When Martin asks his mother why the white boys across the street have been forbidden to play with the King children, she explains about prejudice, prompting Martin to say, "Mother Dear, one day I'm going to turn the world upside down." The richly detailed illustrations capture the times and are striking portrayals of the individuals, with Soentpiet including a note describing his use of King family members and friends as models. The respectful tone of the text is augmented by the large, handsome design, with metallic-blue endpapers and halftone photographs used to accentuate front and back matter. A one-page poem by Mildred D. Johnson, "You Can Be Like Martin: A Tribute to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.," follows the short text, and an afterword adds context and personalizes the book. A testament to one person making a difference, the book is intended to be inspirational--and, in both art and text, it is. Julie Cummins
Copyright © American Library Association. All rights reserved

Card catalog description
Looks at the early life of Martin Luther King, Jr., as seen through the eyes of his older sister.

About the Author
Christine King Farris is the older sister of the late civil rights leader, the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. She is an associate professor of young adult education at Spelman College in Atlanta, Georgia, where she teaches courses in multiculturalism and elementary reading. This is her first book. She and her husband reside in Atlanta, Georgia.

Book Description


Long before he became a world-famous dreamer, Martin Luther King Jr. was a little boy who played jokes and practiced the piano and made friends without considering race. But growing up in the segregated South of the 1920s forced a very young Martin to learn a bitter lesson -- little white children and little black children were not to play with one another. Martin decided then and there that something had to be done. And as a seven-year-old, he embarked on a journey that would change the course of American history.

Renowned educator Christine King Farris, older sister of the late Dr. King, joins with celebrated illustrator Chris Soentpiet to tell this inspirational story of how one boyhood experience inspired a movement. It's a tale that will touch the hearts of all people, and remind us all that if you believe hard enough, dreams can become reality.

The Nazi State and New Religions Five Case Studies in Nonconformity
King, Christine

Reviews

". . . extremely well documented . . . a scholarly work which deserves to be read not only by members of the sects discussed but also by Christians and scholars generally. It fills a gap in the story of Christianity's encounter with Nazism." - Arthur C. Cochrane

"In this pioneering study, Christine King focuses on five of the more important sects in Nazi Germany: Jehovah's Witnesses, Mormons, Seventh Day Adventists, Christian Science, and the New Apostolic Church. With the aid of two principal kinds of source, police reports and the sectarian press, she seeks to explain their very different fates. This leads her to two major areas of investigation: the factors influencing Nazi policy towards religious bodies; and the varying survival strategies adopted by the sects themselves. . . . [A] comparative study of this kind provides an excellent means of analysing the methods and motives of religious persecution, and the possibilities of toleration, in the Third Reich." - European History Quarterly

ISBN: 0-88946-865-6 Pages: 350 Year: 1982

Company news from AMI Semiconductor
Date: 20 September 2001 • Company contact details

 
King rules at AMI Semiconductor

AMI Semiconductor (AMIS) has named Christine King as president and CEO.

Editor's note: Readers of the free Electronicstalk weekly email newsletter will have read this news the week it was announced. Click here to request to be added to the circulation.
AMI Semiconductor (AMIS) has named Christine King as president and CEO.
King most recently managed IBM's multi-billion-dollar semiconductor products business, which was the fastest growing business at IBM in the first quarter of this year.
In addition, she launched IBM's OEM ASIC business in 1993, growing it to the number one ASIC business in the world by 1999.
"Acquiring a CEO with Chris' excellent qualifications is a real coup for AMIS", said Dipanjan Deb, AMIS board member and partner of Francisco Partners, a major AMIS investor.
"Her outstanding relationships with ASIC customers throughout the industry - including some existing AMIS customers - will be a tremendous asset for AMIS immediately and in the future".
"I am very excited to have the opportunity to lead AMIS into what I am sure will be a very bright future", said King.
"AMI Semiconductor's ability to provide the industry with effective highly integrated semiconductor solutions is truly impressive.
Their undisputed technology and market leadership in conversion ASICs and significant technology edge in mixed-signal ASICs give me great ammunition for further strategic growth".
Building off of her experience in ASICs, King also launched IBM's networking technology semiconductor business and previously served as vice president of field engineering programs and global marketing.
Prior to those positions, King held various engineering positions at IBM.

Nonviolent Communication 

Santa Cruz (NVCSC)

 

Promoting and teaching Nonviolent Communication

 in the community of Santa Cruz, California

 

 

 

 

Christine King's undergraduate degree is in the social sciences and she has a K-12 teaching credential. She has a strong interest in understanding why countries go to war and in the 80s she received an advanced degree in international relations at the Graduate Institute of International Studies in Geneva, Switzerland. She has worked for the United Nations, University of California, Santa Cruz Waldorf School, and Santa Cruz City Schools.


Christine has also traveled the world and lived overseas for extended periods of time. She has practiced Buddhist meditation for over 25 years and actively participants in the Santa Cruz Society of Friends. Christine and her husband Mark have two children, Claire 17 and Jack 21.

After hearing Marshall Rosenberg and taking classes with NVC Certified Trainer Jean Morrison in the late 90's, Christine realized that Nonviolent Communication was the missing link between her meditation practice and social action work. She has studied NVC extensively, taking classes, workshops, attending retreats, and international trainings in preparation for her NVC certification. Since 2002, Christine has taught NVC in schools, jail, universities, adult school, and privately. She is passionate about this work and enjoys sharing it with participants of all ages. Christine can be reached at cking@baymoon.com.

The NASDAQ Stock Market proudly welcomes AMIS Holdings, Inc. [AMIS] and its CEO Christine King to the Market Open in celebration of the company's one-year listing anniversary. In conjunction with the Market Open, AMIS will hold an analyst day at the NASDAQ MarketSite.

About AMIS Holdings, Inc. [AMIS]:

AMI Semiconductor (AMIS) is a leader in the design and manufacture of silicon solutions for the real world. As a widely recognized innovator in state-of-the-art integrated mixed-signal products, mixed-signal foundry services and structured digital products, AMIS is committed to providing customers with the optimal value, quickest time-to-market semiconductor solutions. Offering unparalleled manufacturing flexibility and dedication to customer service, AMI Semiconductor operates globally with headquarters in Pocatello, Idaho, European corporate offices in Oudenaarde, Belgium, and a network of sales and design centers located in the key markets of the United States, Europe and the Asia Pacific region. For more information, please visit the AMIS Web site at www.amis.com.
