TDB Home Page > Career Development > MCP > Alumni > Class of 2002 >


P. Christine King

Chemistry Team Leader
CC
(W) 301-496-3386
Email: cking@cc.nih.gov

My career at NIH has taken a circuitous route. Originally from Milwaukee, Wisconsin, I moved to the Washington, DC metro area 18 years ago. I received my baccalaureate degree in Medical Technology from the University of Wisconsin, Oshkosh in 1973, and a Master's degree in Counseling/Educational Psychology from the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, in 1981. While these two areas seem opposite of one another, I have found that both have been invaluable throughout my career.

My first job at the NIH was in the Department of Laboratory Medicine (DLM). For 3 years I worked in the Hematology, and Chemistry areas. I then took a job at the Washington Hospital Center in charge of a very specialized testing area that worked primarily with renal transplant, and nephrology patients. While there, I also taught Medical Technology students. It was very rewarding and led to some publications, and presentations at local and national professional meetings about the testing we were doing. I was also awarded a small research grant to investigate the application of a new in-situ DNA product to patient samples.

During the mid 1980's, in-situ products were new on the market. My experience at the Washington Hospital Center led to a job at a local biotechnology company as their Regulatory Affairs Officer. They were trying to develop various commercial in-situ products. One of my responsibilities entailed recruiting, and working with collaborators for the products being developed. I found in my conversations with them that I missed the laboratory work. This led me back to the NIH as a research technologist at NCI in 1990. At NCI, I continued to be active in my professional society, presenting workshops at meetings and being a contributing author to two textbooks.

In 1991 a supervisory position opened in the Department of Laboratory Medicine (DLM), where I had started many years before. I am currently a Lead Technologist in its Clinical Chemistry Service. The DLM analyzes, and reports results from blood, and body fluid specimens from Clinical Center patients. These results are used to help manage the care of patients admitted to the various protocols at the NIH. We generate some of our own research, as well. I have oversight of a section within Chemistry that performs urgent blood tests, urine chemistry tests, and urinalysis. It requires monitoring quality control, quality assurance, and supervising Medical Technologists that rotate through my group. We operate 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, so sometimes my weekends are not my own.

An accomplishment of which I am particularly proud, occurred last summer. I was inducted into an honorary fraternity for Clinical Laboratory Science which recognizes achievement within the profession.

My leisure time is filled with gardening, and playing old-time (pre-bluegrass) music with my husband, and friends. Although not currently in a band, we have performed for Habitat for Humanity, and for the Fairfax County Park Authority.

Colonel Christine King would be a good Commissioner of Police
Stabroek News
March 9, 2002
Related Links: Letters on the police
Letters Menu Archival Menu

Dear Editor,

The pleasure was mine to have had a brief association with Col. Christine King in the production and presentation of a certain programme. In a recent interview on GTV, she hinted to her imminent retirement from the Guyana Defence Force. This astute woman can offer her country an unmatched service in another position. In this regard, I suggest that President Jagdeo give Guyana an excellent 36th birthday gift by appointing Col. Christine King as Commissioner of the Guyana Police Force. This outstanding soldier would bring to the police force qualities that are vitally necessary to salvage this institution. She has the discipline, the tenacity, the professionalism and the will to create the change at the leadership level where the change is obviously needed.

Col. King as a trained social worker would understand the responsibility of the commissioner's office and the force in securing the social anatomy of the citizenry. She would know that it's the force's responsibility to inform the public and not conduct the affairs as if the commissioner is the institution.

Look at the way the New York commissioner of police fields questions from the press, you get the feeling that he understands that he owes it to the society to make the information available. Where the information is not there he accepts it as his duty to go and find out (investigate). A police force needs a commissioner who will make such attitudes the ethos of the force.

Our security demands that one who understands the power and need for proper example leads the police force. Col. King has singled herself out as such a person. We learned that her rise to the high position she now holds was not as a result of political favour; it was due to hard work and dedication to a cause. She is a fine example to other women who have to labour for recognition in a man's world. When a woman, in a `man's job', rises to such heights without lying low, she is effect says, `I cannot be bought or sold'. Society cries out for such persons.

Col. King's gender may be frowned upon as her greatest obstacle. That is because our socialisation process has nurtured in us this `man's world' mentality. Yet it is probably her best ally, if she were appointed to the post.

Men have by and large been like phantoms. Many of society's important institutions seem to suffer with the disease `menopause' (Men On Pause) a personal adaptation.

Menopause is used here to describe a state in which men have been placed on pause as on a CD player. The CD continues to spin; giving the impression it is in operation. It consumes electricity but provides no music.

Col. King's professionalism will benefit the force immensely. Society abounds with reports of reckless mini bus drivers who are untouchable since they operate vehicles that are owned by police officers. One conductor berated a police corporal at the Plaisance car park. The bus was badly parked and the rank asked the driver to get in line. When he refused, the rank instructed him to empty the bus and go to the Eve Leary station. The driver and conductor instructed the passengers to ignore the officer shouting, `Y'all don' come out de bus, is `e bass (boss) vehicle'. Campaigns are started and stopped just as fast. The road carnage continues unabated. Killer drivers are back in the seat to continue their killings probably to be classified as `serial killers'. While all of this is going on, the authority seems to be helpless, hapless, incapable of rescuing the situation. As a member of the army and a professional. Col. King is untainted with corrupt policing and is therefore capable of promoting values that will lend to restoring dignity and professionalism to the police force.

Yours faithfully,

F. Summer

ACCUSED: Christine King denies poisoning husband Wayne Roycroft around November 19, 1988.
KELLY SCHICKER/Waikato Times

Poison charge nearly decade and a half after disappearance

02 November 2004
By CATHERINE HUTTON

Murder accused Christine King was seen slipping "something" into her husband's beer to "calm him down", Hamilton District Court heard yesterday.

Wayne Roycroft was last seen alive in November 1988.

In June 1989, police launched an inquiry after his family reported him missing.

In 2002, police reopened that inquiry and in May after a tip-off they returned to a Campbell St house in Waihou he shared with King. Police dug up a concrete pad but have never said what was found.

King, who is now remarried, was spoken to again, but details of what she said to police have been suppressed.

King, 50, a beneficiary of Te Aroha, denies murdering Mr Roycroft around November 19, 1988. Throughout the inquiry she maintained Mr Roycroft was alive and in Australia.

Mr Roycroft's mother Aileen told the court yesterday that while visiting the couple she once saw King put something in his beer.

She said King told her it was to make Wayne "not to be violent" and to "calm him down."

Under cross-examination by King's lawyer, Judith Ablett-Kerr, QC, she admitted her son "liked to be boss and was a bit moody". She agreed he liked to drink.

King sat expressionless through the case yesterday, but during her sister-in-law, Maureen Roycroft's evidence she wrote notes and when another witness suggested King's former marriage had been a happy one, she shook her head.

Mrs Roycroft described the couple's relationship as good.

She said she saw them have the "odd fight", usually over the messy house.

Advertisement
Advertisement

Mr Roycroft, who didn't work, was left home with the children while King went off with her family or to work, she said.

King worked as a waitress at the Palace Hotel in Te Aroha.

Asked by prosecutor Louella Dunn about how King coped with these arguments she said King stuck up for herself and usually ended up doing what she wanted to do anyway.

Mrs Roycroft denied ever seeing the two exchange physical blows.

The Crown maintains King killed her late husband by poisoning him.

Earlier, another witness told the court King admitted giving Mr Roycroft sleeping tablets.

June Godfrey, a friend of King's, told the court King had said she put sleeping pills in Mr Roycroft's dinner, so he would not follow her to work.

"The only thing that she really got annoyed with was the way Wayne used to take the mileage on her car and follow her," she said.

The preliminary hearing before Community Magistrate Pat Fergusson is expected to finish today, with many of the 18 witnesses giving their evidence by hand-up depositions.

Hawaiiscars.com

Posted on: Sunday, May 7, 2000

Living and loving exercise

By Beverly Creamer
Advertiser Staff Writer

With dinner over, the King family follows a routine several nights a week: Out come the double baby jogger, the running shoes and the dog’s leash, and off goes the family for a three-mile run through their Enchanted Lake neighborhood.

Though Ryan is only 2 and Kyle barely a year old, the King kids already are getting a taste of what it means to be active as part of their regular family lifestyle.

It’s all part of how to raise children to have a lifelong love of exercise.

"We’re just waiting for them to turn 3 so we can take them skiing," said Christine King, cardiac rehab nurse and supervisor of the Health Education Center at Straub Clinic and Hospital. Husband Don King is a respiratory therapist at Straub.

Nationally, children are fatter, more lethargic and less fit than ever before. They are slumped in front of TVs and computers, slouched on the couch, burning off few calories on the trips back and forth from the refrigerator. One in five children is considered overweight, and three in five are inactive.

But condemning their behavior won’t change it, according to health professionals.

The best way to teach your children to value exercise is to do it yourself. Exercise as a family, and start when they are young, so they’ll grow up believing daily exercise is as natural as breathing.

"Kids follow what their parents do," said Christine King. "You’re the role model in your child’s life."

Give them tennis rackets and baseball gloves as gifts. Schedule birthday parties at the miniature golf course or the beach, or rent one of those giant "bouncer" rigs so they can jump for two hours. Help them to develop not just a love of team sports, but interest and skill in individual sports such as tennis or swimming, things they can do for a lifetime.

"The goal," said King, "is to make it fun. It has to be a game."

When the two King boys aren’t out with their jogging parents and the dog three or four times a week, they are diving for balls at the park with their folks or running around the zoo, or tumbling in the waves at Kailua Beach while hanging onto Mom and Dad’s hands.

"How do you get your kid to value this?" asks Linda Soll, dietitian for the Shape-Down program at Straub. "By the family doing things together.

"So, instead of the family going out for brunch, do an active thing. Go for a walk on the beach. Instead of making all your family things (consist of) going to the movies, go hiking. Or paddling."

"If the child sees Mom walking every morning, it’s very powerful," said Soll. "They want that love so they will emulate her. They see you doing it, and want to do it too."

Soll has found in Straub’s Shape-Down program that there’s greater success trimming down children if parents are involved first. "If you have a couch potato parent saying the child should be walking, you’re going to have a tough time."

Sometimes, said Soll, if parents push themselves to go for a walk with their child, they will find it’s a good family time. And that tradition could lead to better relationships.

But she said she recognizes that families in Hawaii have an additional difficulty balancing our food-centered culture and its fellowship with making active family choices. Expanding the cookout plans to include a game of touch football or a beach swim could provide both.

Research has shown that adult behavior is significantly influenced by habits learned at an early age.

Dennis Kaaihue puts that idea to work in raising his youngsters, 4-year-old Nicole and 7-year-old Joshua, just as he does as lifestyle program coordinator for Kaiser Permanente.

While leading the Wellness Program, he points out that the way you sell something is crucial to children. "It has to be presented in a way kids don’t look at it as a chore."

Never tell kids you’re going for an exercise walk. "We’re going exploring" is better. "It has to be presented so that enjoyment is at the forefront," said Kaaihue.

Don’t use exercise as punishment.

"You see many coaches saying ‘OK, give me a lap for messing up,’" said Robert Daniel, who owns Hawaii Cheer Co., which trains cheerleaders all over the island. "And then you’ll see the kids won’t want to go and do it on their own."

Always keep it positive and fun, said Daniel.

Persuading parents

Eighteen-year-old Christine Nguyen, an instructor with Hawaii Cheer Co., knows firsthand the benefit of athletic activity not just for the skills, but to feel comfortable in a new place.

In elementary school, Nguyen begged her parents to let her take gymnastics after she’d seen it on television. But her immigrant Vietnamese parents at first didn’t value the ideas of exercise and competition, and it "took a lot of convincing," she said.

Nguyen, who now cheers with the Hawaii Pacific University squad, said the classes gave her self-confidence, a sense of accomplishment and motivation to do even better. "Once you see you can do something, you want to do more," said Nguyen.

Daniel noted that exercise is often foreign to immigrant families, who focus on academic achievement in their children. Seeing young people like Nguyen excel may help others see the importance of these kinds of extracurricular activities, he said.

Prenatal routine

Exercise physiologist Mackinley Emmons believes parents can begin family fitness routines even before children are born.

If mothers-to-be are active during pregnancy, some of the endorphins produced end up in the developing child.

While children are infants, parents might want to join exercise classes that pair them with their babies. The message is powerful, said Emmons.

"When you start with young children, they don’t question why your family is going on a hike," said Soll.

An added attraction is to buy children their own, mini-sized gear.

When her now-grown children were preschoolers, the Soll family began hiking and skiing together, and the children had their own little backpacks, parkas "and teensy gloves." It made them know "they are part of it and it’s not just for Mom and Dad, but the family."

Soon, hiking and skiing were family traditions. And traditions can be lifelong.

"The child sees that each summer time we go camping. Or hiking," said Soll. "Now that my daughters have children of their own, they’re going hiking with them."

Other alternatives

Even if a physical disability prevents a parent from being active, there are ways to teach children to value exercise, said Soll.

Show up and watch their games. Praise them for achievements. Support their team sports by helping with potlucks or by shouldering some of the management or planning duties. And focus on supporting what your child is interested in rather than forcing them to do what you think they should.

"When our kids were about 8, we asked them what they wanted to do," said Soll. "One said ‘swimming,’ the other said ‘diving.’ When she started, she couldn’t even depress the board, but she kept with it, and eventually became state champ."

Variety is part of the equation, too. If one thing isn’t catching a child’s interest, try something else. Or try out new things together.

"Get them involved in as many different activities as you can," said Emmons. A smorgasbord of offerings will give them a better idea of what they like, Kaaihue agreed.

Little Nicole Kaaihue wanted to learn to dance, the be-bop kind, not hula, she said. So her folks scoured the town for dance classes and signed her up at the Y.

Meanwhile, when his son wanted to play soccer three years ago, Kaaihue volunteered to coach the team. "It’s walking the talk," he said. "Regardless of what you say, kids notice what you do."

About the Keynote Speaker:

Christine King Farris is a member of an historic civil rights family. She serves as Associate Professor of Education and Director of the Learning Resources Center at Spelman College in Atlanta, Georgia. AMI Semiconductor: Top of Idahos tech list - Pocatello company making waves and profit in industry

February 8, 2004View for printing

AMI Semiconductor http://www.amis.com has been named as one of 50 electronics companies to watch. AMI makes chips for the security and automotive industries, as well as remote monitoring devices.

Christine King, president and CEO of AMI Semiconductor in Pocatello, has been garnering notice as a female leader in a male-dominated industry.

Julie Howard The Idaho Statesman

http://www.idahostatesman.com/Business/story.asp?ID=60536

When the state Department of Commerce went looking for a shining example of an Idaho technology firm to highlight in a recent ad campaign, there was an obvious choice: AMI Semiconductor in Pocatello.

Perhaps you were thinking Micron Technology?

There were some reasons AMI went to the top of the list.

Reason No. 1: The electronics firm continued to grow throughout the economic downturn.

Reason No. 2: Relatively new CEO Christine King was garnering notice as a female leader in a male-dominated industry.

Reason No. 3: The firm chose Pocatello as its worldwide headquarters, relocating from sunny San Diego to the relatively unknown eastern Idaho city.

But thats not all.

AMI Semiconductor was named one of 50 electronics companies to watch in 2004 by Reed Electronics Group. The annual ranking typically spotlights companies that are expected to outperform the market. Micron Technology, a memory chip firm based in Boise, was the only other Idaho firm to make the list and AMI was ranked high above the Boise memory chip company.

***********************

AMI Semiconductor fast facts

History: Founded in 1966 in Santa Clara, Calif.; moved manufacturing operation to Pocatello in 1970; moved headquarters to Pocatello in 1988.

What they do: Design and manufacture integrated mixed-signal and structured digital devices that are used in electronics products in the automotive, medical and industrial markets.

How many employees: 2,500 worldwide; 1,100 in Pocatello

Annual revenues: $345.3 million for 2002.

Stock symbol: AMIS on the Nasdaq stock exchange.

Web site: http://www.amis.com

Earnings due out Thursday

AMIS Holdings Inc., parent company of AMI Semiconductor Inc., will release its fourth-quarter and 2003 financial results for the period ending Dec. 31 on Thursday after the market closes.

*****************

Just last month the Ridenbaugh Press named King the ninth most influential Idahoan and the most influential CEO in that publications annual list, several spots ahead of Steve Appleton, the top executive at Micron Technology, the states largest private-industry employer.

AMI in Idaho is just an incredible story, said Karl Tueller, deputy director of the Idaho Department of Commerce and executive director of the Idaho Office of Science and Technology. It convinces outsiders that theres not just a pocket of high technology industry in Boise, but that its statewide. It brings recognition to the state and to our efforts to promote Idaho as a technology-based state.

New mission

While AMI was founded nearly 40 years ago and has had a manufacturing plant in Pocatello since 1970, a revitalization of this electronics components company is a more recent occurrence. Shortly after Francisco Partners & Citigroup Venture Capital acquired a majority interest in the firm in 2000, new president and CEO Christine King was hired to grow the business.

In the past two years, the former IBM executive has led the firm through some rapid transitions.

In 2002, AMI made two large acquisitions Alcatel Microelectronics mixed-signal business and Microsemi Micro Power Products. Those acquisitions brought a European corporate office in Belgium into the fold, a stronger foothold in the global market, and 900 more employees.

The company now also has sales and design centers in the Asia Pacific region as well as around the United States.

Then, last fall, AMI went public, issuing 30 million shares at an opening price of $20, making the initial public offering the largest in the nation for 2003.

More recently, the company opened what it calls its North American Automotive Center near Detroit, basically an office where AMI sales and design workers can work more closely with automotive customers.

Eastern Idaho powerhouse

AMI, as eastern Idahos largest private-industry employer, is to Pocatello what Micron and Hewlett-Packard Co. are to the Treasure Valley. While Micron and HP give local economic development agencies bragging rights, AMI is looked to in eastern Idaho as the centerpiece for high tech.

In 2002, for instance, AMI was cited as one of the reasons Pocatello was ranked eighth in Forbes Magazines annual Best Places for Business and Careers.

Theyre our largest private-industry employer with about 1,100 employees here, and they have far and away the largest capital investment anywhere in the region, said Ray Burstedt, executive director of the Bannock Development Corp., the economic development agency in that region. Theyre like diplomats when the executives travel, because they say good things about Pocatello and that helps us.

Burstedt said the importance of AMI to the local economy is such that when the firm needed more space for an engineering facility, an unusual partnership was created to make it happen. The Pocatello Development Authority, which is the areas urban renewal agency, provided a no-interest loan. Idaho State University provided the property on a lease basis, and AMI agreed to a long-term lease on the $4.5 million building.

If this didnt happen, AMI could have gone somewhere else or not done the project at all, said Burstedt, of the facility that opened last May. Now, with this partnership, theres the opportunity for professors and students from ISU to work with AMI.

In addition, he added, the new 30,800-square-foot facility helps AMI attract talented engineers who might think twice about locating to an area where job choices are limited.

The growth of AMI and its dominance as an employer in the region of just under 300,000 residents make high technology as an industry a force in eastern Idaho.

According to the Bannock Development Corp., about 15 percent of the regions residents work in the high-tech industry, compared to a national average of 9 percent.

About 10 percent of the Treasure Valleys residents work in the high-tech industry, according to the Boise Metro Chamber of Commerce.

There is a small core of technology companies popping up in the region, fostered by the nearby Idaho Accelerator Center and Idaho State University, and the Idaho National Engineering and Environmental Laboratory in Idaho Falls.

Still, transportation is an issue for companies that conduct business worldwide, such as AMI.

Industry focuses

The creation of the office near Detroit was important to the firms pursuit of the automotive industry.

Its a small office, but its very important that were next to the customer, said Bob Klosterboer, a senior vice president at AMI. Its no simple chore to get from Pocatello to Detroit to work with these guys. This is a way for us to take our automotive product offerings that we are developing in Idaho and make Detroit more aware of them.

Klosterboer says being in Pocatello isnt a drawback for the globally focused firm.

Weve been real successful here for a couple of reasons, including a very stable work force and the quality of life here, he said.

Another area that could prove successful for AMI is its wireless offerings designs that could be used in everything from security systems to interactive toys to remote medical monitoring equipment.

This works in applications where you dont have to transmit a lot of data, said Klosterboer.

Jerry Worchel, a senior analyst with market research firm In-Stat/MDR in Phoenix, has watched the numerous changes since he started covering the Idaho company a decade ago.

Theyre under great management and theres a good solid core of employees, said Worchel. Theyve done very well for what theyve focused on. Theyre a well-established company.

Sales to the automotive industry represent 25 percent of AMIs business. The firm designs, develops and manufactures custom chips used in a number of automotive parts, from ABS brake systems to air bag deployment to headlamp controls.

Worchel said AMI is up against huge competitors such as Motorola and Texas Instruments in selling to the automotive industry, but he added that the firm has proved its expertise in the products it sells.

Now theyre pursuing medical applications, which very few companies have done until recently, he said.

Theres tremendous opportunity for the future in this area. Companies like AMI will give the medical world a way to lower their costs.

The future for the company looks bright, says Klosterboer.

AMI is among the world leaders in structure digital products right now, said Klosterboer.

We are as good as it gets. We have picked a niche we can be very good at.

To offer story ideas or comments, contact Julie Howard jhoward@idahostatesman.com or 373-6618

My Brother Martin
Text by Christine King Farris, illustrations by Chris Soentpiet
When "M.L." was a little boy, he loved to play jokes. This prankster was none other than Martin Luther King, Jr., whose older sister shares funny and moving reminiscences of their childhood. Realistic watercolors and vividly recounted anecdotes show children how this great hero was once a kid like them -- that is, until one life-changing event.

People In The News
Christine King

AMI Semiconductor Appoints Christine King President/CEO

Pocatello, Idaho-AMI Semiconductor has appointed Christine King president and CEO. She joined AMIS from IBM Microelec-tronics' Semiconduc-tor Products.

While at IBM, King also launched IBM's networking technology semiconductor business and earlier served as director of IBM's field engineering programs and global marketing. [amis.com]

APEX Plans New Courses

APEX has scheduled 64 professional development courses for APEX 2002, from January 19-24, in San Diego. [apex2002.org]

Karl Suss Expands Asian Presence with Taiwan Center

Munich, Germany-Sus MicroTec AG, the holding company for Karl Suss, has opened a sales and service support center in Hsinchu, Taiwan. The Taiwan expansion follows the company's April expansion into Shanghai, China. [suss.com]

'Survey' Winners Get Book

Three participants in Chip Scale Review's recent salary survey were randomly selected to receive autographed copies of Charles A. Harper's recent McGraw-Hill publication, Electronic Packaging and Inter-connection Handbook.

David Chapman of Circuit Service Inc., Wheeling, Ill.; Fernando Chen of Legerity Inc., Austin, Texas; and Dr. Nancy Dean of Honeywell Electronic Materials, Spokane, Wash., won copies of this authoritative work, courtesy of McGraw-Hill. [mcgrawhill.com]

Dr. Claudio Truzzi

Dr. Truzzi Leaves CS2; Forms Packaging Consulting Firm

Maastricht, Netherlands-Dr. Claudio Truzzi, most recently director of engineering and technology at packaging foundry CS2, Belgium, has left to form his own consulting business.

Known as Convergix (from Convergent Electronics), Dr. Truzzi will specialize in advanced packaging technologies. [claudio.truzzi@convergix.nl]

FSA Releases Wafer Survey

San Jose-The Fabless Semiconductor Association (FSA) has released its second- quarter wafer-pricing survey. The survey gauges the average price paid per wafer by fabless companies. [fsa.org]

Paul Lin

PBGA Co-Inventor Paul Lin Joins Kulicke & Soffa Industries

Willow Grove, Pa.-Paul Lin, co-inventor of the Plastic Ball Grid Array, has joined Kulicke & Soffa Industries as director of process integration, based in Milpitas, Calif. He will report to Jack Belani, president of the company's Wire Bonding Division.

Lin will focus on integrating K&S substrates with probe, assembly and test processes used in the development of advanced IC packages.

The holder of more than 50 patents, Lin was most recently founder and president of Array Packaging Technology Inc., Fremont, Calif. Earlier, he was vice president of product management for the Alphatec Group, Santa Clara, Calif.

While at Motorola, where his posts included director of packaging development, he co-invented the PBGA, fine pitch quad flat pack with molded carrier ring and several other industry-standard packages. Lin earned a master's degree in physical metallurgy from the University of Minnesota and a bachelor's degree in mining/metallurgical engineering from Chung Kung University in Taiwan. [kns.com]

FeinFocus USA Hires Dupree as Regional Sales Manager

Stamford, Conn.-FeinFocus USA, a supplier of x-ray inspection systems, has named Jon Dupree regional sales manager for the company's northern territory.

Based in Nashua, N.H., Dupree will manage an area which includes the northern Midwest, eastern Canada and New England. Prior to joining FeinFocus, he was an independent manufacturers' representative for assembly products. [feinfocus.de]

Wayne Moore

AIT Adds Veterans Moore, Shaw as Vice Presidents

Pleasanton, Calif.-Wayne F. Moore and George A. Shaw Jr., have joined Advanced Inter-connect Technologies Inc. as vice presidents.

Ron Cates

Moore, who was most recently president of Signetics High Tech-nology Inc., San Jose, was appointed AIT's vice president of sales and special accounts. Shaw, who will be based in Hong Kong, joined AIT as senior vice president of operations from Amkor Technology Inc., where he held a similar post in Asia. Earlier, he was president of Alphatec U.S.A. [aitsales.com]

Peregrine Semiconductor Names Cates Photonics VP, GM

San Diego-Peregrine Semiconductor, a supplier of ICs for optical networking and wireless communications, has named Ron Cates vice president and general manager of its photonics division.

Cates most recently served as vice president of the Broadband Access Business Unit at Conexant Systems, where he spent eight years in the development and marketing of DSL ICs and subsystems. [peregrine-semi.com]

Conference '99

3. PARTNERSHIP: A BETTER DEAL FOR LEARNERS

Main points of the presentation made by Prof. Christine King, Vice Chancellor, Staffordshire University; Chair, Staffordshire Learning Partnership

Professor King spoke of the need to move from competition to coherence and remove the barriers posed by multiple funding streams and learners being perceived as commodities in an out-put driven system.

The National Context

It is important to start with a strong commitment to:

  • recognising the diversity of organisations all working towards the same goal

  • simplifying the picture

  • building on the best of past practice

  • identifying geographical boundaries

  • making change happen.

Principles

The principles of the Staffordshire Learning Partnership are to:

  • improve information and guidance. Higher quality information is needed showing pathways through each stage, including steps into and through employment

  • increase access, remembering learners' needs, not providers' systems

  • stimulate demand. There are many yet to reach. It is important to put the relevant provision in place at the right time

  • improve the quality of their products and services, helped by the appropriate use of ICT

  • engage those we are 'losing' at present. In Staffordshire, 19 per cent of 16 to 18-year olds are neither in employment nor study.

"gaps and duplication [in learning provision] are one of the biggest issues we have to address. We all know how difficult and sensitive this is. But if we can't, as a partnership, do some serious strategic planning which alters the provision we offer individually, we will not succeed."
Prof. Christine King

Starting Point

In beginning life as a Learning Partnership, the Staffordshire group's starting point was to:

  • establish local learning needs - by understanding who our current and potential customers are

  • eliminate duplication and identify and address gaps in provision - this involved open sharing of information and a willingness to address difficult and sensitive issues that might involve releasing resources to other partners

  • pull together different strands of activity on which the different parties lead. We had to be creative and find linkages between different and complementary programmes

  • develop a strategy for marketing opportunities. We had to find ways of badging activities effectively and communicating with one voice. It does not matter to the learner which organisation the offering is from

  • determine the quality and appropriateness of opportunities. Students deserve the best and quality is a big issue.

The Challenge

How will the Partnership fit into the new and emerging post-16 arrangements? In Staffordshire we believe we have a new job to do that cannot wait.The challenge is to:

  • press on with our task through this period of change

  • find new ways of inter-acting with the newly-created bodies and strategies

  • seek common funding methodologies to help achieve our aims

  • put learners' needs at the heart of all we do.

There is also much to do to include the voluntary sector, trade unions, private sector and the community as equal partners. If we can draw together those strands and play to their combined strengths, we will make a difference.

The job has to be done now, it won't wait until 2001. If Learning Partnerships did not exist we would have to invent them.

"if it is to be, it is up to us".
Prof. Christine King

NIACE Committee Structure

The Company Board has overall responsibility for the direction of NIACE, and the Board meets at least three times per year.  The Company Board Directors are the Trustees of NIACE, and are elected at the appropriate Annual General Meeting (held in September/October each year) for up to a 3-year term of office.  The AGM also considers for approval the audited accounts, and balance sheets, with the annual reports of the Company Board and auditors.  The AGM appoints the auditors.
Company Board Members

The Policy Committee (formerly The Executive Committee), which meets at least 3 times a year and acts on behalf of the Company Boards, consists of members elected by and from the corporate and individual members of NIACE.
Policy Committee Members

An Assembly, chaired formally by the President of NIACE, has been established in place of the previous Council.  Meeting twice a year, and open to non-members as well as members, the role of the Assembly is to advise the Policy Committee.

The Finance and General Purposes (F&GP) Committee, which meets three times a year, is responsible for the review of financial implications for NIACE, especially in relation to funds, staff and premises.

William Allen White
Children’s Book Award
 

 Current Master Lists

 

 

Each year the William Allen White Children’s Book Award Committee creates a Master List of titles, chosen from books published during the previous year. Since 2000, there have been two Master Lists, one for 3rd to 5th Grade and one for 6th to 8th Grade.

2005-2006 Master List: Grades 3-5

2005-2006 Master List: Grades 6-8

Past Master Lists

See the following pages for more information related to the current Master Lists:

  • Curriculum Guides
  • Downloads
  • Voting Online
  • Calendar

Master List: Grades 3-5

Buchanan, Jane. The Berry-Picking Man. New York, Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 2003.
Hardback ISBN: 0374406103
Paperback unknown
Subject Areas: Old age, Family life, Christmas, Empathy
Synopsis: Nine-year-old Meggie resents spending time with a strange, smelly old man who calls her mother whenever he needs a ride, but when Christmas finds him in the hospital she knows what she must do.

Clark, Clara Gillow. Hill Hawk Hattie. Cambridge, MA, Candlewick Press, 2003.
Hardback ISBN: 0763619639
Paperback planned September, 2004
Subject Areas: Fathers and daughters, Death, Rafting, Logging, Sex role
Synopsis: Angry and lonely after her mother dies, eleven-year-old Hattie pretends to be a boy and joins her father on an adventure-filled rafting trip down the Delaware River in the late 1800s to transport logs from New York to Philadelphia.

Codell, Esme’. Sahara Special. New York, Hyperion Books for Children, 2003.
Hardback ISBN: 0786807938 (trade)
Paperback ISBN: 0786816112
Other formats: Cassette tape, Compact disc
Subject areas: Teacher-student relationships, African Americans, Self esteem, School, Authorship, Chicago

Paperback ISBN: 0689870671

Paperback unknown

Paperback not planned

This killer has a name – yellow fever – but everything else about it is a mystery. Its cause is unknown and there is no cure. This powerful dramatic account by award-winning author Jim Murphy traces the devastating course of the epidemic. An American Plague offers a fascinating glimpse into the conditions in American cities at the time of our nation’s birth while drawing thought-provoking parallels to modern-day epidemics.

Placement of Orders: Purchasing entities must use both the instructions on the contractor's web page and the terms and conditions in the federal supply schedule to place orders. Purchasing entities may use a either a departmental purchase order or the contractor's on-line ordering system to place orders. Purchasing entities may opt out of using the contractor's on-line ordering system if it is incompatible with the entity's purchasing procedures. The contractor is not required to accept orders below the minimum listed below. Orders between the minimum and maximum listed below are subject to GSA preferred customer pricing. For orders above the maximum, purchasing entities are entitled to negotiate for lower prices than those listed on the on-line federal supply schedule price list.

Payment Due Date: Payment will be due on the thirtieth (30) calendar day after the later of: (a) the date the State actually receives a proper invoice at the office designated in the applicable purchase order to receive it; or (b) the date the State accepts the products or services. The post mark date on the envelope for the State warrant (State's equivalent to a check) or banking information showing when a direct deposit transaction was received will be considered the date payment is made. Interest starts accruing on the first day that payment is late. The rate of interest for late payments is set at one percent per month.

 Comment  |  Education egweekly  |  Special report: University access

Opinion

Understanding access

'Fair access' means different things to different gifted and talented people says Christine King

Tuesday April 15, 2003
The Guardian

The Office for Fair Access is a great idea. So great, indeed, that I have suggested to several of my VC colleagues that they join me in a job-share application for the director's post. No takers so far.

I suppose the important thing is what "fair access" will mean. Access comes with many hats. The words "access", "widening participation" and "inclusion" are used interchangeably, as fashions in vocabulary change. They mean very different things, however, and here's the joy of the challenge for Offa, and indeed for all of us.

The danger, of course, is that Offa gets stuck on the newsworthy but relatively insignificant question that is the modern equivalent of "how many angels can sit on the head of a pin?" - that is, "how many 18-year-olds from working-class backgrounds can get to Oxbridge?". How easily we could lose the plot totally and become obsessed with only one model of access. There are, in fact, at least four.

Model One. Let's call it the "access" model. A wealthy, research-led university decides, or is told by government (Laura Spence, little did you know ...) that its student population does not reflect the social balance of society. Seeing this as a fair comment (or not) elite University X goes out into the highways and byways and seeks potential students with a minimum of four As at A-level but from a working-class school and home. The four As (minimum) are necessary because the university is based on the principles of independent learning and the said students must be able to survive. Staff will teach and teach well, with a passion for their subject, but they also research. Remedial help is not on the agenda.

Model Two. Let's call this "widening participation". Research-intensive, elitish University Y wishes to offer its courses to a more diverse student group. It also, for financial reasons, needs to expand. On examining its cohorts, it sees it has few students from a particular area or set of schools. It has a super library and its students "read" for a degree. Its staff (for the time being) also research. So students will need to learn independently, with the right (but not too much) support.

However, even closer examination of the chosen target groups reveals that not all are likely to achieve enough A-level points. An expedition is thus sent forth, backed by government money, for the university to run "master-classes" and summer schools so these students can catch up. Once admitted, they become like all other students and the widening participation work is done.

Model Three is the speedy route to this solution. University Z needs to expand, so it buys a nearby college campus and keeps all its working-class students safely there. Remember the ad about Remington razors and the guy who liked them so much that he bought the firm? This is the educational equivalent. Hey presto, targets reached, money collected and university size expanded. Done deal.

Model Four is when a university, instead of opening its doors to a few more of the "gifted and talented", meets its students where they are. A note on the "gifted and talented" government initiative says it all. This seeks to find the "brightest and the best" and to bring them "up to a standard".

All our students at Staffordshire University are gifted and talented. Some of those talents are marked by brilliant A-level grades, some by the skill in overcoming disability or disadvantage, some by both. Others have gifts that manifest themselves in totally different ways.

A Model Four approach - strangely accused of being Mickey Mouse - recognises that what people come out with, rather than what they come in with, is what matters. This model, which I hope and intend that my university will continue to embrace, doesn't lead to high league table positions.

However, it does mean working closely with partners in further education and elsewhere and it sees students soar - achieving more than they and we could have dreamed of, whether in absolute or relative "value-added" terms. The very nature of the university is changed by them. We have to look again at when we open, where we teach, what we teach, what skills for employment and life we aim to give. Yes, there is a greater risk of drop-out; yes the costs of giving that extra learning support are high; but the results are a joy to behold.

Of course, this is all a caricature. I have terrific admiration, for example, for one of our leading universities, Leeds, for its widening participation and for the respect it gives to diverse models of inclusion.

Until we stop pretending that all access is the same; until we offer mutual respect for what all parts of the system are trying to achieve; until we are willing to challenge the insults and the league table silliness, little will change. Offa could help us break this cycle. So, that job-share: any takers?

Christine King is vice-chancellor at Staffordshire University.

Character Descriptions
The Irissas From "iris," meaning rainbow. In the vampire community they are the oldest, the teachers, guiding their family.
Gilda Born in Bravel several hundred years before this story takes place. In this life she is the madam of Woodard's, a bordello in New Orleans. She is the partner and lover of Bird.
Bird Born in the Philippines, she was brought to the United States with her mother when she was young and was left with a Lakota Indian tribe after her mother's death.
GildaGirl Escaped (at age 12) from slavery in Mississippi when her mother died. She was taken in and educated by Gilda and Bird at Woodard's.
Theodora Two years older than GildaGirl, she is a free black whose fair-skinned mother used to work in the bordello. She works as a domestic servant and lives at Woodard's.
Fox An ex-slave who appears to be in his 20s but is closer to 100.
Savannah Originally from the South and in her mid-30s, she is a hairdresser at Gilda Nite Styles.
Skip A musician who is a couple of years younger than Savannah.
Toya A young prostitute from New Orleans who came north to make money.

::: Friday, January 16, 2004 :::

The price of vanity?

Filed under:
  • OBITUARIES
- Slobokan @ 11:42:45 [Printer Friendly]

Best-selling author Olivia Goldsmith has died after her facelift went wrong.

She was best known for The First Wives Club which was turned into the 1996 hit film starring Goldie Hawn, Bette Midler and Diane Keaton as three friends who take their revenge on cheating husbands who dump them for younger women.

The 54-year-old writer, whose real name was Justine Rendal, had been in a deep coma for more than a week caused by a reaction to an anaesthetic while she was having plastic surgery.

She died last night at the Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan after failing to regain consciousness during an operation at a clinic on 7 January to remove skin from under her neck.

Rest In Peace, Olivia.  

Obiter Dicta (0)

Respectful legacy.

Filed under:
  • TOPICAL EVENTS
- Slobokan @ 09:58:27 [Printer Friendly]

In a sign of the difficulty President Bush faces as he tries to win black support for his reelection, several hundred protesters loudly booed him on Thursday as he laid a wreath at the grave of civil rights leader Martin Luther King.

The President of the United States pauses for a moment to pay tribute to one of the most influential people in American history, and people boo him?

The president was accompanied by King’s widow Coretta Scott King, and sister, Christine King Farris. He placed the wreath, bowed his head for a few moments, and departed without speaking or facing the protesters as the boos from the crowd increased.

Whether you agree with his policies or not, whether you think he is a decent person or not, whether you are civilized or not, he is the President of the United States and should be shown respect. Especially when he is standing at the grave of Martin Luther King, paying his respects.

The protesters carried signs with slogans like “Money for jobs and housing, not war” and “It’s not a photo-op George.”

After watching the news last night, it appeared to me that it was the protesters using the moment as a photo-op.

The protesters themselves showed utter disrespect for Martin Luther King, as well as Coretta Scott King, Christine King Farris, and President Bush.

Here are links to resources on obesity:

  • NZ Links and other resources

New Zealand

  • Dietary Interventions to Prevent Obesity in Primary Care: A Literature Review, Robyn Whittaker, Public Health Protection, September 2001 (pdf 78kb)
    Obesity is now recognised world wide as a significant public health problem. In New Zealand, more than half of the adult population is overweight or obese, and reducing the prevalence of obesity has become a population health objective. Prevention of obesity is thought to be easier, less expensive and potentially more effective than treatment, however there has been little research into methods for prevention in Primary Care. Go to http://www.arphs.govt.nz/publications/Publications.asp and scroll down to Obesity Prevention Review to get .pdf
  • Carryer, J. B. (1998). Challenging Society's Outlook of 'large women'. Official newsletter of the New Zealand Dietetic Association (113) 10-11.
  • Carryer, J. B. (1998). Medicalisation of body size. 6 November, New Zealand Society of Gastroenterology, Palmerston North.\
  • Carryer, J.B. (1999). Is Xenical a real solution to a real problem?. Women's Studies Seminar Series, Massey University, August 2, Palmerston North, NZ.
  • Ryan, K. & Carryer, J. (2000). The discursive construction of obesity. Women's Studies Journal, 16 (1), 32-48.
  • Carryer, J. (2001). Embodied Largeness: A Significant Women's Health Issue. Nursing Inquiry, 8 (2), 90-97.
  • Childhood obesity &151; not just &145;puppy fat&146;
    In 1997, obesity cost New Zealand $135 million in healthcare. Obesity is the major cause of preventable diseases such as diabetes, heart disease and high blood pressure.While there are many factors causing obesity, the two most commonly identified are a sedentary lifestyle andpoor nutrition. Physical inactivity is directly associated with 8% of all deaths in this country and only 40% of all adults are sufficiently active, according to the Ministry of Health. There is insufficient information about the role nutrition plays in obesity and the dynamics that prevent existing knowledge about healthy nutrition and exercise from being applied. Research, although far from conclusive, is beginning to suggest that obesity in childhood can lead to a continuation of the problem into adulthood. The government is about to embark on a national childhood nutrition survey to address the currently fragmented picture of childhood obesity. Christine King has been part of Ministry of Health focus groups for the development of healthy nutrition and physical activity standards and was a member of the expert group that created an Obesity Tool Kit in 2001 for district health board use. She has commenced a research programme at UNITEC to study the effects of physical activity and nutrition on obese children. In this seven-month study, 20 intermediate school age children considered overweight were brought to UNITEC, where they were given a healthy afternoon tea and an opportunity to exercise through games. This was supplemented by evening nutrition sessions for the whole family. These sessions were useful in gathering information about what children of this age actually ate, as well as providing an opportunity to offer nutritional advice. The children were weighed and measured at different times throughout the project, given questionnaires about eating habits and physical activity, and asked to keep food intake diaries. Results from the programme have been encouraging. A significant proportion of the children had only minimal weight increases associated with increases in height, and some had decreased in waist measurements. A number of children were clearly more confident and comfortable playing games as a result of their participation in the programme, increasing their self-esteem. One of the schools involved is now intending to start a similar afterschool games programme for its students. Environmental (including school environments) and socio-economic factors are likely to underlie any lack of attitudinal change in this country towards physical activity levels and nutritional habits. Most children can no longer walk or cycle to school because of distances and safety issues, and many children appear to be making their own food choices because both parents work. Poor attendance at the evening nutrition sessions throughout the programme was, for example, thought to be due to parental work schedules. The relationship of poverty to food security and obesity requires more research, as do the family dynamics that keep poor nutritional habits in place. Schools have a part to play due to the kinds of fatty foods they continue to sell in canteens. Local shops, which offer ice creams, chips and takeaways, are also linked to poor nutritional habits and obesity. Christine&146;s study will contribute to the information to be gathered from the national nutrition survey, suggesting as it does that the application of this knowledge is still lacking in homes and schools despite much effort going into public education about healthy lifestyles. Obesity prevention thus needs to be addressed within a social context and at an early age. Christine King (School of Sport, Faculty of Health and Environmental Sciences) is a registered dietician and nutritionist. She lectures in sport and exercise nutrition at the School of Sport and advises athletes and teams for the New Zealand Academy of Sport. Her professional interests are in sport and exercise nutrition and she has been involved for many years in community nutrition work. cking@unitec.ac.nz
  • King, C. (2001). Ministry of Health Expert Advisory Group Report on the Obesity Toolkit.

    MONDAY, June 30 (HealthDayNews) -- Obesity raises the risk of death from colon cancer in women, but not men.
    More at: http://www.healthday.com/view.cfm?id=513904

To download Healthy Weight New Zealand 2001 click on the following link.  Healthy Weight New Zealand Report 2001
  • Grant No. 981
    The APPLE Study: Pilot Design.
    Ms Rachael Taylor (Funded by the Southland Medical Foundation) Because of labour saving devices, changing preferences for leisure activities and an abundant food supply, we live in an environment which promotes obesity. Thus in order to reduce obesity, we need to educate people about healthy lifestyles but also ensure that a healthy lifestyle is available to everyone. #Therefore we need to know if removing perceived barriers to a healthy lifestyle actually changes behaviour. The aim of our project is to assess what factors promote obesity in children in several small towns, in order to develop a suitable intervention programme that attempts to change those factors which promote obesity.

Obesity and Cancer: A deadly link

The risk of dying from cancer increases significantly for both men and women who are obese, according to a new study published in the April 24th, 2003 issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. This increased risk is shown to affect women more often than men. Being overweight or obese, categories defined by measuring body mass index (BMI) accounts for roughly 14 percent of cancer deaths in men and 20 percent of deaths in women, according to the results of the study.

In this prospective study, researchers from the American Cancer Society examined the relationship between BMI and death from cancer in more than 900,000 adults. They found that increased body weight raises the risk of death from all cancers combined and from cancers at multiple specific sites. In addition, among patients in the heaviest weight category, with a BMI greater than or equal to 40, the risk of cancer death was 52 percent higher in men and 62 percent higher in women when compared with normal weight adults. BMI is calculated by dividing weight (kilograms) by height (meters) squared.

Women are affected more often than men for several reasons. Many studies have established a strong association between breast cancer risk and increased body weight and only a modest association between prostate cancer and obesity. "Obese women double their risk of breast cancer," according to Dr. Carmen Rodriguez, MD, MPH Senior Epidemiologist at the American Cancer Society and one of the authors of the study. Therefore, increased body weight plays a more significant role among women compared to men suffering from the most common forms of cancer. In addition, Dr. Rodriguez explains: "the percentage of obese women is higher than men, 33% versus 28%."

The incidence of obesity in the United States has increased significantly over the last two decades. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, obesity is defined as a BMI greater than or equal to 30. To be classified as overweight, the BMI is between 25 and 29.9. Recent data from the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Maryland, shows that roughly 31 percent of the adult population aged 20 years or older meet the criteria for obesity. And the numbers continue to rise.

While the reasons underlying the association between cancer death and obesity are not fully understood, female hormones are thought to play a role. "Obesity increases the risk of breast cancer only among post-menopausal women," explains Dr. Rodriguez. Because many post-menopausal breast cancers are stimulated by estrogen and fat increases circulating hormones in the body, the risk of cancer increases for obese women.

Obesity has been linked to many serious health conditions, including cardiovascular disease, diabetes, stroke, and high blood pressure. According to Dr. Rodriguez, there aren't many studies showing that weight control programs lower the risk of cancer death: "We can speculate that if you lower your weight, you will lower your risk as well. But it is not easy to do an observational study with enough people who have been obese and lower and maintain their weight." She recommends maintaining a healthy weight as well as good nutrition and exercise habits throughout life.

May 1, 2003

by Jennifer Wider, MD
Society for Women's Health Research

SOURCES
 Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, BMI worksheet.
National Center for Health Statistics, factsheet.
Calle E, Rodriguez C, et al. Overweight, Obesity, and Mortality from Cancer in a Prospectively Studied Cohort of U.S. Adults. NEJM. 2003; 348:1625-1638.

Dangers of Obesity Extend into the Womb

Women who are obese prior to pregnancy increase the risk of birth defects to their children, according to a new study published in the journal Pediatrics. In addition to regularly monitoring their weight gain during the course of their pregnancies, all women should be mindful of their body weight even before conceiving.

In a population-based case-control study, researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, Georgia interviewed hundreds of women to determine the relationship between prepregnancy weight and certain birth defects. They found that obese women were more likely to have an infant with spina bifida, a neural tube defect; omphalocele, a defect in the development of the abdominal wall; and heart defects. An increased risk of heart defects or other congenital anomalies was also seen in overweight mothers who did not quite meet the criteria for obesity.

The participants' weight was determined by calculating Body Mass Index (BMI), weight in kilograms divided by height in meters, squared. The risks for obese women and overweight women were compared with those for normal-weight women. Obese women were defined as those having a BMI greater than or equal to 30; overweight women were defined as those having a BMI between 25.0 and 29.9; normal-weight women had a BMI less than 24.9.

"The reason(s) for the greater risk among obese women is/are not known," explains lead researcher Cynthia A. Moore, M.D., Ph.D. of the National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities. Dr. Moore and colleagues discuss several possible mechanisms for the correlation between excessive maternal weight and birth defects. They propose abnormalities in metabolism of glucose, insulin or hormones, which may affect the development of the fetus. They also explain that overweight women are at greater risk for gestational diabetes, or diabetes of pregnancy, which has been linked to an increase risk of birth defects. In addition, women who are pregnant require 400 micrograms of folic acid daily in order to prevent neural tube defects. The researchers suggest that heavier women may need increased requirements of certain nutrients like folic acid to prevent defects in their fetuses.

The incidence of obesity is on the rise in the United States and it has become increasingly clear that weight control can have a dramatic effect on the health of unborn children. "From this study, we have identified that women who are at a healthy weight before pregnancy lower their risk of having a child with certain birth defects than do women who are obese; therefore, prevention efforts should focus on attaining a healthy weight before pregnancy," according to Dr. Moore.

There are several other measures women can take to ensure healthy pregnancies. Dr. Moore adds, "(Women can) abstain from alcohol and smoking during pregnancy, discuss all medication use with their doctor, and take a multivitamin with (at least) 400 micrograms of folic acid daily." These simple actions can significantly improve the chances of having a healthy baby.

Several other tips for a healthy pregnancy are available at the Web site: http://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/bd/abc.htm.

May 13, 2003

by Jennifer Wider, MD
Society for Women's Health Research

Sources
Watkins ML, Rasmussen S, Moore CA, et al. Maternal Obesity and Risk for Birth Defects. Pediatrics 2003; 111(5): 1152-1158.

www.horseinfo.com

Preventing Colic in Horses

by Dr. Christine King

Colic can be deadly to horses.  Colic is the most widely reported malady affecting horses of all breeds and ages.  Most incidences are not life threatening and do not require surgery, but the danger exists.  Dr. Christine King tells you how colic develops, how to recognize it when it strikes and how to prevent it in your horses.  Just a few simple management practices can eliminate colic from your barn.

 

Prevention of colic focuses on management. You will learn management strategies that include:

  • Matching the horse's natural diet as closely as possible

  • Matching the horse's natural feeding schedule as closely as possible

  • Matching the horse's natural activities as closely as possible

  • Minimizing changes in diet, housing, and activity level

  • Feeding only good quality foodstuffs

  • Ensuring ample access to fresh, clean water

  • Maintaining a good deworming program

  • Maintaining a regular schedule of dental care

  • maintaining good environmental management

  • Paying attention to your horse!

 

WI 03-120  Preventing Colic in Horses by Dr. Christine King, Softcover, 192 pps., $24.95

Picture Books 

Daisy Comes Home by Jan Brett
     Mei Mei has the six happiest hens in China. But one of the hens, Daisy, is not always so happy. One night when Daisy is asleep in a basket, it drifts into the river. This is the begining of a great adventure. Jan Brett's exquisite illustrations reflect life on the Li River and the mysterious and beautiful countryside through which it flows in this heartwarming story of a brave little hen. Fans of Jan Brett will be thrilled with this latest book.
 

Fiction




Same Stuff as Stars by Katherine Paterson
     Due to unfortunate life circumstances, young Angel Morgan and her brother Bernie have moved into their great-grandmother's crumbling Vermont farmhouse. Grandma, aged and poor, spends most of her time wrapped in a blanket by the wood stove and can't care for the children. In this dreay world a mysterious stranger appears on clear nights and teaches Angel about the stars and constellations. Angel's quest to carve out a new life for herself and her brother makes for a powerful, moving story. Angel is one little girl not soon forgotten!

Stand Tall by Joan Bauer
     Tree is twelve years old and too tall--six feet, three and a half inches and growing. He wonders when he'll stop, and wonders when people will stop expecting him to be good at basketball, start acting older. Wonders if he'll ever get used to living in a different house every week now that his parents are divorced. Tree has his Vietnam vet grandfather to help him. Grandpa knows about overcoming since he's just had part of a leg amputated. He alwasy speaks the truth, just like Tree's new friend Sophie. This is a story about accepting things, including yourself. It is packed with memoralble characters and bighearted humor, and is about finding purpose in tough times. And it's about Tree's big heart, not his size, making him a hero.

Journey to the River Sea by Eva Ibbotson
     Life has taken a strange turn for Maia, an orphan living in London in the early 1900s. She must leave the cheerful school that has been her home to stay with unknown relatives in Brazil. This is a story of great adventure and mystery , and Maia is a terrific heroine.
 
 

Non-Fiction

Down a Sunny Dirt Road: An Autobiography by Stan and Jan Berenstain
     In alternating voices, this enormously readable account first tells of the early years before Jan and Stan met, andr eaders will be struck by the similarities between two young people of such different backgrounds. This book chronicles their lives through the creation of America's first family of bears!

G is for Golden: A California Alphabet by David Domeniconi
     This beautifully illustrated book introduces children to the cultures, history, and natural beauty of California. Longer expository passages engage older readers looking for those "fun-to-file" facts. Fun for young and older alike!

My Brother Martin: A Sister Remembers Growing Up with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. by Christine King Farris
     Reknowned educator Christine King Farris, older sister of the late Dr. King, joins with celebrated illustrator Chris Soentpiet to tell this inspirational story of how one boyhood experience inspired a movement. It's a tale that will touch the hearts of all people, and remind us that if you believe hard enough, dreams can become reality.

Woody Guthrie: Poet of the People by Bonnie Christensen
     This book celebrates the life and times of an American original--the great folk musician Woody Guthrie. With brief, lyrical text, and brilliant woodcut-like illustrations, Bonnie Christensen has created a stunning picture book that is at once a biography for Woody's youngest fans and a moving ode for folksingers of all ages. 
 


For Teachers and Parents

Best Friends, Worst Enemies: Understanding the Social Lives of Children by Michael Thompson, Ph.D. and Catherine O'Neill Grace
       Drawing on new research as well as their own extensive experience in schools, the authors demonstrate that children's friendships begin early-in infancy-and run exceptionally deep in intensity and loyalty. As children grow, their friendships become more complex and layered but also more emotionally fraught, marked by both intimacy and cruelty. This book brings to life the drama of childhood relationships, guiding parents and teachers to a deeper understanding of the motives and meanings of social behavior.

Girls will be Girls: Raising Confident and Courageous Daughters by JoAnn Deak, Ph.D.
      In this book, JoAnn Deak gives us the solutions to the problems addressed in Reviving Ophelia. She offers a road map to the many emotional and physical challenges girls ages 6 to 16 face in today's changing world.

Odd Girl Out: the Hidden Culture of Aggression in Girls by Rachel Simmons
      If your daughter has ever come home from school upset because her friends wouldn't walk with her to lunch, if she has wanted to stay home or has run up to her room in tears and won't tell you why, you may want to read this book. these may seem like minor problems, but they aren't, and they can have a lasting effect on a girl's self-esteem. The secret world of girls' aggression is just as harmful as the aggression of boys, but it's harder to recognize. Girls are not encouraged to express their anger, and so it goes underground. Odd Girl Out sheds the light of understanding on the secret lives of girls. Simmons helps us see where the behaviors come from, and offers teachers and parents ways in which to help our daughters. Odd Girl Out names the problem, describes it, and offers advice on how to deal with it.

Queen Bees & Wannabes by Rosalind Wiseman
      In her groundbreaking book, Empower cofounder Rosalind Wiseman takes you inside the secret world of girl's friendships. She has spent more than a decade listening to girls talk about the powerful role cliques play in shaping their lives. In this book, she dissects each role in the clique, discusses power plays, and takes readers into "Girls' World" to analyze teasing, gossip, and reputations, and more.

A Mind at a Time by Mel Levine, M.D.
      Different minds learn differently. Dr. Levine shows parents and teachers how to identify these individual learning patterns. he explains how parents and teachers can encourage a child's strengths and bypass the child's weaknesses. This type of teaching produces satisfaction and achievement instead of frustration and failure.

Raising Cain: Protecting the Emotional Life of Boys by Dan Kinldon, Ph.D, and Michael Thompson, Ph.D.
     Two of our country's leading psychologists share what they have learned in more than 35 years of combined experience working with boys and their families. They illuminate the forces that threaten our boys, teaching them to believe that "cool" equals macho strength and stoicism. Cuttting through outdated theories of "mother blame", "boy biology", and "testosterone", the authors she light on the destructive emotional training our boys receive-the emotional miseducation of boys.
